17001.name: Battle Command
17001.description:
Generic land battle strategy board game. Box measures 20" x 11 1/4". Single-fold mounted color game board with 21 x 19 one-inch-square grid superimposed to regulate movement. Terrain represented includes Mountain, Forest, Plains, Fords, and Rivers. Multi-square Airfields also represented.

Miniature plastic pieces include Tanks, APCs and Airplanes (six Tanks, six APCs and three Airplanes per side; complete set of each in Yellow, Brown, Green, and Blue). The APCs are eight-wheeled turreted vehicles strongly resembling a USMC LAV. Tanks resemble a cross between the US Army M-109 SP gun and an Israeli Merkava tank. Airplanes slightly resemble early speculative depictions of a Stealth fighter with twin tails and an unflattering forward-swept projection on the leading wing edge.

All of these units are moved according to the roll of two six-sided dice. Die results are added together; the sum ("dice units") is allocated among friendly pieces for movement.

Terrain costs vary for Tank and APC units. Pieces may be moved in any direction including diagonally, but may not stack together or pass through an occupied space.

All unit types have a "range" of two spaces. Tanks may not attack Airplanes (unless all friendly Airplanes are destroyed). Airplanes must be "airborne" in order to attack (they must "take off" down the "runway" of their "airstrip").

Combat is resolved by die roll, "attacker" and targeted "defender" each rolling one die. The result of subtracting low roll from high roll is referenced to a "Battle Chart" yielding a result of "Safe," "Disabled" or "Destroyed." APCs are destroyed on a difference of "1" or more. Tanks are "disabled" by a difference of "1" or "2" and "destroyed" by a differential of "3" or more. Airplanes are "destroyed" by a differential of "3" or more vs. another Airplane or an APC or a "4" or "5" if beaten by a tank. Airplanes are "disabled" by a "1" or "2" differential vs. another Airplane or an APC.

Destroyed units are removed. Disabled tanks are turned on their side. "Disabled" tanks may be "captured." A friendly or enemy APC may "capture" a "disabled" tank by moving adjacent and surviving until the next friendly turn. At the start of the next friendly turn, the tank is turned rightside-up and is considered friendly to the capturing player.

Disabled Airplanes "crash land." The "disabled" Airplane travels three spaces in a straight line (in any direction the owning player chooses) and is turned upside-down. During this "descent" the Airplane may "pass over" other units, but the space it "crashes" in must be vacant. An APC (friendly or hostile) may "recover" the downed Airplane in the same manner as a Tank is recovered; however, when the Airplane is turned rightside-up, it is immediately returned to a friendly Airbase parking space.

"Disabled" pieces may be attacked and destroyed instead of being captured if a player so chooses.

A unit may only inflict damage on the first unit to attack it in a given turn. If a piece survives an initial attack and is attacked again, it rolls in defense as usual, but will not inflict any damage on its attacker even if its die roll is higher.

Airbases may be captured by disabling or destroying all hostile pieces on the Airbase and then occupying at least one square of the Airbase with a friendly Tank or APC.

The object of the game is to be the last player with a surviving APC unit.

Rules include options for a short game with less equipment. A small paper insert, dated 1991, provided a simpler version using the same movement rules but capturing by simply moving a piece onto an opposing piece space, moving and capturing until all "dice units" have been used.

The box art painting accurately portrays the pieces inside. One of the modernistic tanks advances firing, evading a near miss while the moon lights APCs crossing a stream to the rear in Ardennes-type terrain as jets swoop above. The title "Battle Command" appears in large red letters all the way across the top of this illustration. In smaller white letters across the bottom: "A Fast-Playing Game of Strategy, Daring, and Chance!"

In the lower right corner is the logo of "Precision Toy," white letters superimposed over a line of evergreens with the title and evergreens "reflected" oppositely beneath. The back cover features a large black-and-white photo of the board and components. "Precision Toy" was located in Julian, CA 92036. The game was made in USA.

17002.description: Based on the Houndcats animated series, this is a typical early 70's spin the dial and move game. The object of the game is to be the player that reaches the most "trouble spots" at the end of the game ("Sparkplug to the rescue!"). A deck of cards is shuffled and the first card is drawn and placed on the appropriate spot on the playing board. Each player then spins the dial once, and EACH player must move their playing piece with the intention of reaching the spot with the trouble card (the spaces on the spinner have a number 0,1,2, or 3, related to each players color so during each spin, each player moves their playing piece the number of spaces indicated for the color of their playing piece). Pieces can move forward or backwards and any number of players can occupy the same space. Once a player lands on the card that represents the trouble spot, the card is taken by that player and a new card is drawn and the process repeats.
17002.name: The Houndcats Game

17003.description:
Published in 1905 by Milton Bradley (catalog #4384). Game is played with a deck of 40 color lithographed cards depicting various comical scenes. The object of the game is to "capture" all of the cards, this is done in the following manner.

1. Deal the cards equally among the different players, keeping them face down.

2. The player at the left of the dealer begins the game by taking off the first card of his pack, and placing it on the table face up, and the play continues to the left until each player in turn turns up the first card of his pack in the same manner.

3. When any player sees two cards which are alike turned up on the table, he may call out "SNAP", and the one first calling takes all the turned up cards in both places where the duplicate cards appear.

4. The successful player takes all cards won and places them face downwards under his original pack and must then play his first card upon the table.

5. The game continues as above until one player secures the entire pack, thereby winning the game.
17003.name: Snap

17004.name: Table Croquet
17004.description: Published circa 1890's, this is Milton Bradley catalog #4334. The game is identical to regular outdoor croquet but is packaged in a small box and the supplied pieces allow player to re-create the game on a smaller table top. Interior of the box includes both the rules and a diagram for the arrangement of the posts and wickets to accommodate a rectangular playing surface. Mallets are about 8" long, balls are 1-1/4" in diameter, and hoops are 2" in diameter (and are supplied with small wooden feet so they will stand erect).

17005.name: Bonaparte
17005.description: Bonaparte is a strategic game of Napoleonic campaigns in Europe, between 1807 and 1813. It is mainly a "France against England" game but it also includes management of 11 other nations. This game is a wargame including logistic management and diplomatic aspects. The object of the game for the French player is to make allies of all the European countries except England. The game can also be played by four players, adding an Austro-Prussian and a Russian player, both trying to maintain their independence.

17006.name: Arcanor
17006.description:
Played on a board of 8 x 7 squares. The 2 players have 12 cylinders with the top closed (3 small of 4 value, 3 medium of 3 value, 3 big of 2 value, and the 3 biggest of 1 value). They can be put one on another like Russian dolls. At the beginning of the game, the 12 cylinders are on the line before their owner (6 under the 6 others). The object of the game is to bring 12 value points on the line before the opponent. When a player takes a turn, he can :

take one of his cylinders and make it "eat" a foe cylinder next to it (8 directions) of a size immediately smaller
free the cylinders under a top friendly cylinder by moving it in an adjacent square
simply move to an adjacent square , a friendly cylinder or group of cylinders in which the top cylinder is his




Players must add memory to tactics in order to remember what cylinders are under the others.

A winner of the 1994 Concours International de Créateurs de Jeux de Société.

17007.name: Fairway
17007.description:
A Golf game.
A 9 holes board, 6 playing pieces, 5 different dice (one for each club type), Bunker cards, Trouble cards, banknotes and a set of papers to mark score.
A hole course is divided into a grid of squares. The player taking his turn chooses what club (and then what die) he wants to use. He moves his marker according to the result of the die throw in direction of the hole, and so on until the piece lands on the hole square. He can move it vertically on the fairway, and horizontally or vertically on the green. He notes the number of strokes he used and the next player takes his turn. When everyone has played the hole, everbody starts the next hole, and so on until 18 holes are played (the 9 hole twice).
If the piece lands in a bunker, a Bunker card is drawn and executed. If the piece lands in trees or rough, a Trouble card is drawn and executed. If the piece lands in water or out of bonds, the golfer plays again (the bad stroke is counted).
Money is gained for different reasons (hole winner, par done...). The winner is the one who gains the more money. Alternative game makes the player who played the less strokes the winner.

17008.name: Award Show
17008.description:
Become an award winning game designer...AT HOME!

The game is played in six rounds each for a different award. In each round each player is secretly assigned to be one of six game companies. Players then place cards on each of six companies nominated for that award. The card range in value from -1 to 2 votes. At the end of the voting, each player, beginning with the dealer, chooses one company to have its votes tallied. When the total tally of all non-negative votes is eight, the company with the most votes wins. If a player controls that company he gets that card and any other cards where votes were tallied.
Game ends after six rounds and the person who has collected the most cards (not necessarily the most awards) wins.

Components: Two-deck tuck box comes with 100 whimsically illustrated cards and rules.

17009.name: Schmear!
17009.description:
SCHMEAR! is the build-a-bagel card game with round cards.

Turn over the cards and match up slices and toppings in a contest to build the biggest bagel sandwich.

But watch out: If you add a life preserver, a CD-ROM or an old tractor tire, your sandwich is wrecked and it's the next person's turn.

At the end of the game, score 1 point for each complete bagel, plus 3 bonus points if you've got the biggest bagel of them all.

17010.name: Midway
17010.description:
This is a Japanese wargame on the Battle of Midway, 1942.

Published as one of the SS(Small size war Simulation) series in 1990.

17011.description:
Containing six scenarios spanning three wars, this Module includes all the supplemental rules and data needed to carry the CoA system through the Arab-Israeli Wars. Each scenario includes an 8 1/2" x 11" map, a brief historical commentary and tables with all pertinent data extracted for the players' convenience.

Although this module was designed to be used with CoA system, the scenarios can be easily adapted for use with other tactical armor systems.
17011.name: From Golan to Sinai. The Arab-Israeli Wars 1956-1973

17012.name: Imagination Station
17012.description:
Back of the box says:
Set out on your very own fantastic, fun-filled treasure hunt. Use Whit's inventions to search for the Diamonds of Virtue. Be the first player, or team of players, to recover one of the Diamonds of Virtue, then return it to start and you win!! It's that easy.

Players try to collect three different cards to complete a diamond jewel they collect from landing on special spots. Movement is determined by dice and by landing on time warps that allow moving to other parts of the board.

17013.name: At Whit's End
17013.description: It's a fast-paced, room-to-room race that will test your knowledge of history, the Bible and, of course, Adventures in Odyssey. Draw a Charades card, and step onto the stage in the Little Theater to give the performance of a lifetime. Move to the Room of Consequence...but only if you’re prepared to reap what you sow. Pick a Draw card, grab a pencil and get creative. But make it fast--your next move will depend on it! Be the first to leave each room successfully and you win!

17014.name: 1869: The Golden Spike
17014.description:
This is a game in the 18xx system, set in the Western United States, and dealing with the building of the first transcontinental railroad and its aftermath. It has many special features:

1. Bonds to encourage the first transcontinental railroads to build track along historical routes.
2. Land grants to add extra income.
3. Connection bonuses.
4. Special city tiles that add extra length to trains that run through a token there.
5. Refurbished trains.
6. Palace cars (trains that double the value of one city run through with another train)
7. Mergers (some forced, some optional)

Overall, an interesting attempt, but the bonds seem quite out of balance, so that victory in the game seems determined by who owns the most Union Pacific and Central Pacific shares after the first stock round.

17015.name: The Original Intersection
17015.description:
"The Original Intersection TM" is the humorously intended title of a game that owes almost all of its creative inspiration to Parcheesi, the Westernized version itself of Pachisi. The designers are simply experimenting to see how little they have to change to come up with their own game that will make them a million dollars in royalties, (or at least a tidy income so they can design MORE games without otherwise having to work) and thus, avoiding copyright infringement lawsuits. As such, it IS a useful and instructive game, as it is almost certain that they would have made more money had they simply reproduced the original public domain version and sold it.

The game differs from Parcheesi in that it has a jazzier layout, where the players move in a more complicated journey around a mazelike path of concentric circles. An additional option is the ability to play as a "partner" with other players, moving your partner's pieces once yours are all safely "home".

Though the board itself IS reasonably attractive, this is purely a "novelty" game, purchased for no other reason than that probably nobody else had ever seen it. It is one step away from a total "home production", in that the parts are made nearly as cheaply as possible. Indeed, though it looks totally unplayed, the box is so flimsily designed, that it is bent in several places. The tokens are push pins with the pins removed to save production costs.

17016.name: Hunny Pot  Picnic
17016.description:
Hunny Pot Picnic is a simple game for very young children. The game includes a hunny pot with a spring operated spinning ball shaped indicator to determine whether you get the hunny and can play the turn, or whether the bees appear and you have to pass the turn. There are circle discs (called Tokens) with Pooh's friends (Tigger, Piglet, Eeyore, Rabbit, and Roo) on one side, and a Hunny Pot on the other side. There is also one Pooh Token.

Hunny Pot Picnic has two difficulty levels of play:

Level One: Is a simple collection game to collect the most Tokens. If the Hunny Pot doesn't show bees when it is activated, you collect a Token. The player with the most Hunny Tokens wins.

Level Two: Requires some memory skills. You collect Tokens with the Hunny Pot indicator, but the object is to get each one of Pooh's friends. If you flip over a Token of a Pooh friend you have already collected, you turn it back over, so that other players can remember where it was and collect it.

17017.name: Golferholics
17017.description:
From the website:

The idea of the game is to imagine yourselves out on the golf course playing a relaxing game of golf - but - it is a board game and is meant to be light-hearted and entertaining, so there are a few hiccups along the way - and - you must bear in mind you will be very much at the mercy of the dice.
Played as near to real golf as possible with 2 dice, 1 black and 1 white. The black for the fairways bar the four short holes. The white for the four short holes and all eighteen greens.

The black and white dice cards are used when each dice rolls a 'c'

All the various games can be played e.g Stroke play, Foursomes, Fourball, Match play, Stableford etc. Up to 4 players at a time. Serious golfers can deduct their handicaps.

Joy for all the family and friends. Fun to try and beat 'Dad'

Ages 8 and up

17018.description:
With a bit of luck from the dice five beads can be threaded onto the string so that the caterpillar quickly reaches the apple and may eat as much as it wants.

A threading and dice game with wooden game board for 2 - 4 players.

<!-- Entry audited by (nsolitander) (08-11-2009) --!>
17018.name: Threading Caterpillar

17019.description:
From the inside cover:
"Rules for wargames with miniature figures from the days of the earliest Pharaohs of the new Kingdom through the end of the "Dark Ages" - 1500 B.C. to 700 A.D. and slightly later."

This is a 68 page docu-bind style book. Early Gary Gygax miniature rules with illustrations by Greg Bell and Mimi Roach. Edited by Timothy J. Kask.
17019.name: Classic Warfare

17021.description: Bronto and T-Rex compete in the race. But only a dice showing a dinosaur will bring them closer to their target. Bad luck, if a bone or an egg appear on the dice: the dinosaur has to stop moving. A stoney strong dice competition for 2 - 4 players.
17021.name: Dinosaur Dice

24865.name: SITS Ship Book 2: The Silesian Confederacy

17022.description:
Space Combat in the Universe of Honor Harrington!

Saganami Island Tactical Simulator uses the critically acclaimed Attack Vector: Tactical Game Engine to put YOU in command of the ships of the Honorverse. Thrill to the long range missile duel, dancing in 3-D vector space, unleashing the fury of laser heads. Or close in to "kissing distance" and unleash the titanic fury of grasers and lasers! Extensively researched, SITS has new material on the ships and doctrines of the Royal Manticoran Navy and the People's Republic Navy that have never been published before. Mixing rich tactical depth with easy to use Newtonian movement, SITS builds on the novels details to set the tactical parameters for the Honorverse combat

Fully 3-dimensional, SITS has two game scales - the tactical game scale has 12 minute turns, and 1 light second hexes. The system scale has 25 light second hexes, and 1 hour turns, making the pursuit to the hyper limit a challenging tactical puzzle. Every warship in the series will be statted out over the release schedule of this product line, as well as additional ships approved by David Weber himself. Innovative rules allow you to incorporate "The Honor Factor" without unduly distorting the tactical game engine.

SITS offers complete tactical control. You are in command of a hundred-thousand ton cruiser plying the pitiless depths of space.
Fast, simple and highly accurate Newtonian movement rules. Turns take 10 to 20 minutes, a typical game runs 3 to 10 turns.
Accurate, intuitive 3-D movement system, allowing combat to break the plane of the map, and giving unprecedented tactical depth.
17022.name: Saganami Island Tactical Simulator

17023.name: Spell-a-Word
17023.description:
From the rule book: "Spell-a-Word is a crossword dice game The object of the game is to build words and run up the highest point total before time runs out. The Winner is the player with the highest score after 6 rounds of play."

The letter-dice are rolled, and arranged so all players can see the letters and their scores clearly. The egg timer is started, and each player tries to spell words using only the exposed letters. These words must be recorded on a crossword-style scoresheet, which contains several spaces with word-value multipliers. After time runs out, both vertical and horizontal scores are taken, a penalty is applied for each letter left unused, and scores are compared.

Contents:
13 letter dice
1 dice cup
rule book
"Spell-a-word" blank crossword score sheets
egg timer

boardgamehonor.8859: 2006 Golden Geek Best Family Board Game Nominee

17025.description:
In Friday the 13th, also available over the years as Poison and Baker's Dozen, players try to avoid bad luck by not taking cards from the central playing area each round. The more you take, the worse your score — unless you manage to take the most of one suit, in which case you get to throw those cards away!

In a round, each player gets a hand of cards, with the cards coming in three suits that have values from 1 to 7 and a fourth "joker" suit in which all the cards have a value of 4. On a turn, a player discards a card from her hand onto a pile of the appropriate color (with jokers being playable on any pile) and gives the sum of all cards now in that pile. If the sum is higher than 13, then the player must first take all of the cards already in the pile, leaving only her card behind.

The round ends once all the cards have been played, then players compare how many cards they have in each of the three suits; whoever has the most cards throws them away, while everyone else scores 1 penalty point per card. Each joker is worth 2 penalty points. Whoever has the fewest penalty points after each player has started a round once wins!
17025.name: Friday the 13th

17026.name: Top Dogs
17026.description:
From the Playroom Entertainment website:

"Mush! It's dog sledding time! Welcome to Alaska, where our team of dogs led by the Musher of your choice is ready to compete in the Iditarod.

In Top Dogs, players must pick their best combinations of dogs to form the strongest team to compete for each race and win the trophies of different values. But, other players have the same dogs to choose from and the competition can become sneaky!

As soon as each player has chosen their team, each set of dogs are evaluated for team strength and the trophy is awarded. So jump on your toboggan and choose wisely in this dog-eat-dog game of psyching out opponents."

boardgamehonor.8858: 2006 Golden Geek Best Kids' Board Game Nominee

17027.description:
The aim of Sitting Ducks Gallery is to use your 'dead-eye' aim and cunning to shoot your opponent's ducks and ensure that your ducks are the last ones remaining in the Gallery.

The player's are presented with a Sitting Ducks Gallery in which the player's ducks will appear as new cards enter the central row and occasionally some empty spaces too.

The players must then use cards in their hand to aim at particular ducks of choice. Once a duck has an aim token over it any player can play a 'Fire' card to shoot them and thus eliminate the duck from the gallery. When a player has all of their ducks eliminated they are out of the game.

The player's also have access to many special cards that allow the line to be manipulated. Results can be the movement of ducks, however Aim Tokens do not move and in this way a player an protect their ducks and threaten those of the opposition.

The game play is similar to Guillotine in the way that the line can be manipulated and the special effect cards on offer.
17027.name: Sitting Ducks Gallery

17028.name: Spacelab
17028.description:
The aim of the game is to build a spacelab from several components. The players compete to bring up the most modules. Therefore they need to buy launch pads, rockets or the shuttle and the components itself.
There are different types of rockets that vary in their ability to carry one or more modules and how much weight they can accept. Rockets can be used only once, whereas the shuttle is reusable.
The game ends when one of the players picks the last module, rocket or extra card. The player with the most money (earned by successful installed modules) wins.
The components are very well done for a self-published game, the first edition held 211 copies.

17029.name: Der ehrliche Charly
17029.description:
Three to Five players compete in making the most money bartering about used cars.
Everyone sells and buys some and you *try* to make the most out of it. This is not easy since every player has several cards depicting upgrades (few) and defects (PLENTY) that are played face down on the cars that are currently traded.
The "lucky" winner of a bid collects the depicted worth of the new car from the bank plus any present upgrades, pays the agreed price to the car dealer and then he needs to pay for all the defect cards played upon this card. More often then not he has less money then before the deal. So now he's eager to sell one of his cars to someone else, the only way of getting "save" money.

17030.description:
Like all the other games in the Anno Domini series the Lifestyle edition contains 336 cards. One side of each card names an event while the other side gives the date of the event. At the start of the game every player receives 9 cards with the event side up.
During the game the players add card after card to a growing row of cards while trying to maintain a correct chronological ordering. Instead of adding a card a player can challenge the last player. If this happens all the cards in the row on the table are turned date side up. If the cards are ordered correctly the challenger must take two new cards as penalty. Otherwise the player that placed the last card receives three additional cards.
The aim of the game is to be the first player who adds their last card to the row of cards on the table giving a correct chronological ordering.

Part of the Anno Domini series
17030.name: Anno Domini: Lifestyle

17031.description:
Imagine a quite clean, well arranged house...
Imagine now from two to six children living in this house who have of another idea in their head to leave their toys everywhere... Imagine finally Papa, Mama and Grandmother who follow them and make them clean up their toys! Here, you obtain CAPHARNAÜM, a game in which each one moves a child of which the goal is to be 1st to get rid of all its toy tokens. But each player also moves the adults with an aim of annoying his/her brothers and sister (and to obtain peace!). CAPHARNAÜM is a game about family in which the players more "aguerris" will quickly see the interest to be combined punctually for the greatest misfortune of their adversaries...
17031.name: Capharnaüm

17032.description:
Between 1861 and 1865 the American Civil War was fought. A bloody war in which over 600.000 soldiers lost their lives.

In Bonnie Blue it's your decisions that will tell if the soldiers in your squad will die or live.

Bonnie Blue is a miniature game where 2-6 players control 4-10 soldiers each.

Expanded by:


Bonnie Blue vid fronten
Bonnie Blue och Indianerna
17032.name: Bonnie Blue

17033.name: Bonnie Blue och Indianerna
17033.description: A expansion for Bonnie Blue that adds rules for Indians in the 18th century.

17034.name: Counterterrorist
17034.description:
15mm tabletop game owing a nod to computer games like Rainbow 6 and Counterstrike. Comes in a box with 11 miniatures, one 128-page book (the rules are about 14 pages - the rest is lists and background), two dice and a tape measure.

The heart of the game is an action point system with straight d10 rolls used to resolve actions. Combat is a lengthy process where you have to hit, wound and beat an armor save (yes, it's Warhammer 40k all over again) and then see what injury you delivered. Armor and injury saves are not modified by weapons, so whether you took a hit from a derringer or an anti-material rifle makes no difference to the target - a rather silly outcome, but there you have it.

There is a point buy system, a lengthy compendium of weapons & equipment (many of them with quite unrealistic stats) and a number of light vehicles (civilian models primarily - no tanks or APCs).

17035.name: Attrition
17035.description:
Alternative Armies' second attempt at a game in their Ion Age universe, this transports the action to the world of Golgotha, the "last battlefield" of the Great War. It also modifies the background found in the Firefight game which ostensibly takes place in the same setting. It uses the Ion Age miniatures produced by their company.

There are 3 factions - the Confederacy, the Khanate and the Trators (a mixture of mercenaries and scavengers). Players can play in either 15mm or 28mm scale - the army lists differ, with the smaller scale featuring larger vehicles like tanks. A points buy system is provided - players will control a squad or two in a typical game.

The basic game system is fairly straightforward, using a 10-sided die and centimeters. All players move (using jumpacs for extra speed), then all units fire, with the latter normally being simultaneous. Roll to hit - on a successful hit, you inflict damage, generally by chipping away at the opponent's armor and wound totals. Heavy weapons will generally vaporize a target in one hit and have enormous ranges - consequently they dominate the game. Finally, there is melee, which, as is typical for a science-fiction game, is generally more lethal than ranged combat.

The game itself could either be purchased as a PDF file or as a bound rulebook of about 94 pages (11 of them rules with another 17 pages of optional rules, most of which are geared towards providing a campaign system).

17036.name: The Picture This Game
17036.description:
Based on the obscure Summer 1963 game show, players are divided into teams of two. When it is a team's turn to play, one player is designated the "instructor" and another member is designated the "artist". The instructor chooses a game card not seen by the artist. The instructor has sixty seconds to describe to the artist how to draw the object on the card in terms not related to the object. The artist has to guess what the object is to score. Players play a predetermined number of rounds and the team with the highest score wins.

Picture This is the only home game based off a series that aired only as a Summer replacement. The copyright date appears nowhere on the box, but we assume it was released to coincide with the series.

17037.description:
Ever find yourself stuck somewhere where you'd kill for something to do for a couple of hours. How many games of Tic-Tac-toe can you play? This book gives rules and example games for one hundred games. There are a few old favorites. Some are board game adaptations for the paper and pencil world, and there a many new creations by the author. The book has 10 pages of graph paper in the back for "gameboards". All you need is a pen.

A partial list of the games that appear in this book include:
Nim
Fox and Geese
Paper Halma
Supermill
Killer Beans
Dead Sheep
Infection
Dance of Numbers
Billiards
Robot War
Numeri

Published in 2002.
17037.name: 100 Strategic Games for Pen and Paper

17038.name: Blazing Jets
17038.description:
Building on the successful foundations of Biplane Barmy, Blazing Jets is a game of modern aerial combat, with the emphasis on quick play (ten minutes or less) and tactics over luck.

This game is purchased in as a printable download in PDF format from RPGnow.com.

Rules included : 81 page book, USAF Jargon Guide, 286 Counters, Rules for Vietnam and Gulf War I, Maneuver Charts, Play maps

17039.name: Ship of the Line
17039.description:
Play out classic sea battles of the age of fighting sail using the Ship of the Line rules. The pdf has everything you need to play (except dice) including rules, maps and counters. Ship of the Line is for two or more players and a typical game will take an hour or less to finish.

Ship of the Line includes full rules for: All manner of ships; Unusual vessels; Fortifications; Islands, reefs, shallows, harbors and other terrain types; Ammunition types; Crew quality; Prize money and rules for campaign play; random scenario generator; Scenarios; Extensive notes.

Downloadable from rpgnow.com

17040.name: Zauberlehrling
17040.description:
[translated from the publisher’s description]
A magical game of chance

Who will be the lucky guesser and the first to manage to place all their tiles? A cheerful murmur rings through the magic caves: Each year the apprentices meet to compare their clairvoyant abilities. But only the best can win the magic contest.

Each child has their own magic equipment, which they place on the four different magic objects and five tiles. Each round two children play a game with one another. One child secretly divides his magic objects between his two hands. The other chooses one of the hands and looks at what it holds: Are there magic objects whose tiles they hold? If so, they can put them aside.

17041.description:
subtitled: Napoleon's victory over Austria, 1805.
Nap´s most famous Battle was fought on December 2, 1805 between the French Army under Napoleon and Russian-Austrian forces under Prince Kutusow, also known as the three- Emperor- Battle.

The game is part of the La Bataille series, designed by Monte D. Mattson and Dennis A. Spors based on the Award winning system of Larry Groves / D. Spors. This simulation is a game on battalion/ regimental scale, a true monster with nearly 1000 counters.

scale = 100 m/hex;
time = 20 min/GT;
strength = 50-100 men/SP (Regimental/Brigade Size)

One of the best games in the series. With the unit density low, there is room for some maneuver - D. Spors
17041.name: La Bataille d'Austerlitz

17042.description:
This is the original version of Doctor Faust. It is themed as a Schnitzel hunt, or 'paper-chase' around an oval track. The animals chase after a wooden 'fox and cooking pot' piece. Each turn you have 7 points to use for placing a card, moving the fox and moving one of your own two pieces. Cards are placed face down next to the track and another player landing on one must end his turn, reveal the card and move the indicated number of spaces (1,3,5,7 or 9 spaces back, 2,4,6 or 8 spaces forward).
If the fox reaches any player's piece or a player moves his piece up to the fox, a score card is taken. One is also taken each time the fox is moved over one of the two 'fox' spaces on the track. The game ends when the last score card is taken.
17042.name: Rufus

17044.name: Riombo
17044.description:
Players sail their canoe down the River Ombo trying to get the most 'stick' currency. On a player's turn everyone secretly chooses a number of sticks and then reveals them. The total number of sticks determines the number of spaces the player must move. Many of the spaces make the player lose sticks or gain sticks. At the end of the river a player chooses to take 10 sticks or to 'double' his canoe causing all event spaces to double their effect on the next journey down the river.
Players must use bluff and guesswork to try to land on the good spaces and avoid the pirate spaces. The first player to get 80 sticks wins.

17045.name: SomeBody
17045.description: A collection of five human anatomy games, designed for children 6 on up. There are different levels of complexity for each game. You draw cards relating to the different body parts and attempt to place it into the correct position, and at a higher difficulty answer basic anatomy questions. At times you will draw a body breakdown card that will force you to discard the afflicted body part. This is an educational game designed to teach children basic and not so basic human anatomy. Even parents may learn something new.

17046.name: OMASHI
17046.description:
From the game package:

Omashi is the fun new game of sticks and stones that can be played many ways almost anywhere. It's easy to learn and will provide many hours of enjoyment for your family and friends

Omashi is also a game that allows you to use your own imagination to create whole new ways to play it! So if you think about it, when you have the game Omashi, you don't have just one game - you have many games in one.

Omashi, the addictive low-tech game for the 21st Century and beyond.

17047.name: 5 Score
17047.description: In 5 Score, players try to create combinations of numbers and colors from cards. There may be multiple ways of scoring; the players must try to set up their own scoring opportunities while depriving their opponents.

17048.name: Rail Race
17048.description:
Game components: Game board map of Britain, 6 metal steam locomotive playing pieces, route cards, incident cards, dice and a dice shaker.

Object of the game: Travel from a south coast town to a northern town and back. The route cards determine which towns must be passed through. The incident cards contain events that can hinder movement.

17049.name: Chauvinist Pig
17049.description: Object of the game is to collect 6 cards which, put together, form a picture of a pig. then, to complete the course and undertake the final test at Chauvinist Pig's tail ...

17050.name: Stumblebum
17050.description: A charades-based game where performers roll one or two dice to determine the physical challenge(s) - like “stand on one leg” “eyes closed”, "hum a song", "hand on head", etc. Given the physical challenge(s) the performer attempts to act out a short list of words (in 30 seconds). Get teammates to say the words and your team scores. If not, your opponents can steal the card on their way to collect five cards.

17051.name: Myths and Legends
17051.description:
Greek MYTHS & LEGENDS To Learn While You Play

A deck of 52 nicely illustrated cards consisting of 13 Greek myths, with 4 cards per myth. The object of the game is to collect the most points by collecting myth cards telling the stories. It is played in the manner of The Game of Authors or Go Fish.

For example, the Voyage of Odysseus myth includes cards for Odysseus, Scylla, Charybdis and Penelope. A phrase that is one-quarter of the myth is told on each card's text.

Other myths include Zeus Conquers, Heracles' Labors, Apollo's Island, Aphrodite Marries, Athena's City, Jason & the Argonauts, Persephone Kidnapped, Leda & the Swan, Helen Abducted, Theseus Kills Minotaur, Rhea's Trickery, and The Afterworld.

There is also a pronunciation card: Charybdis = keh RIB dis, Elysian = ee LEESH en, etc.

17052.name: Clash of the War Galleys
17052.description:
Ancient naval conflicts during the Age of Antiquity (Sparta, Athenians, Persians, Phoenicians, Romans).

This is a tactical naval battle game with flat models - Bimarines and Trimarines with arbalists, catapults, Greek Fire, and corvuses.

The game appears to come with only one scenario.

Instructions are provided on how to construct the paper ships (coloring and mounting).

The map area (not provided) would be set to a grid 36" x 36" with 3" squares in which to place terrain (not provided) and your ships.

Game duration is between 5 and 10 turns. With a turn the following events take place;
1) Check Wind & Weather changes.
2) Determine which player conducts an Action (roll a die or flip a coin).
3) Ship or Fleet Action is conducted only after rolling dice and comparing the results to Ship Efficiency.
4) Combat occurs during an Action. It is usually simultaneous.
5) Actions are continued until every ship has had an opportunity to take an Action.
6) Adjudicate loss of ships from fire, ship capturing, etc.

boardgamehonor.8858: 2006 Golden Geek Best Kids' Board Game Nominee

17053.description:
Rise and shine! The Pancake Queen, the Ladybug Queen, and ten of their closest friends have fallen under a sleeping spell and it's your job to wake them up.

In Sleeping Queens, players need to use strategy, quick thinking, and a little luck to rouse these napping nobles from their royal slumbers. The twelve queen cards lie face-down on the table. On a turn, you take one action from the cards in your hand: play a king to awaken and claim a sleeping queen, play a knight to steal someone else's queen (unless she has a dragon for protection), play a wand to send a queen to sleep once again, use a jester to try our luck with the top of the deck, or discard one or more number cards to draw more cards. Each queen card has a point value on it, and whenever all the queen have been awakened or one player hits the point threshold, the game ends and whoever has the most points wins.
17053.name: Sleeping Queens

17054.description:
Pegs & Jokers Ages 7 and up (2 to 8 players)

The joker reigns supreme in this family game of luck and simple strategy! Link the gameboard segments together and select your colored pegs. Now take turns moving your pegs around the board by playing different playing cards. It's a race around the board!

Play a five and move your peg five spaces. Play a ten and you may move your peg ten spaces. But an ace only moves you one space ahead, and an eight will move you backwards!

Just when your peg is almost all the way around the board your opponent can play a joker and send you back Home! Win the game by moving all five of your pegs to your Home space first!
17054.name: Pegs and Jokers

17055.description:
Player 1: We've got a situation here, Colonel. Our embassy personnel in the Hyraxian capital city have been kidnapped by a rebel faction and are being held hostage. The local government can't do anything about it; the rebel influence on their ruling council is strong enough to veto any action. So you and your Rangers are going to take some action. You've got four C-130's and your ready-response battalion, and we can get you some flying air support if you think you need it. Load 'em up, move fast, rescue the hostages, and bring 'em home. If you can't fly them out, we'll set up a rendezvous in-country to get you out by choppers. Rangers, lead the way!

Player 2: Success! The American ambassador and his assistants will make excellent bargaining chips in our struggle. And the existing government can do nothing; our political operatives have seen to that. You, Major, must see to the safety of our "guests." You can expect a rescue operation from the Americans -- they have a long history of meddling in our nation's affairs. Colonel LeMeow of our Intelligence section will take command of the prisoners tomorrow. Until then, guard them well.

Rangers! is a 2-player Expansion for the free wargame Gators! depicting a modern US Army Ranger airborne operation.
17055.name: Rangers!

17056.name: Jungle
17056.description:
This is the 5th of the "Bonsai Game" of daVinci, complete games on a single card (board on a side, rules on the other side).
The board is divided in 12 squares, containing snakes (negative points) or apples (positive points). The players alternates in placing two fingers of one hand on two free contiguous squares. For each covered apple, the player scores a point, for each snake, he lose a point.
The first player places on the board the fingers of the left hand, then the second player places the fingers of both hands, then the first places the remaining hand, and then the players alternates removing and re-placing any hand.
The winner is the first that scores 30.

17058.name: Uri Geller's Strike!
17058.description:
Players compete moving the special "Sensotrons" around a map of Europe searching for the locations of hidden minerals, shipwrecks and treasure.

Once you have moved the number of moves shown on the throw of a dice you have the chance to answer a question. Answer correctly you move again and answer another question.

When your "Sensotron" locates some treasure if you answer the next question correctly you gain gold bars as a reward, if you answer incorrectly you gain a bent spoon (this is Uri Geller's game!).

The player that gains the most gold bars wins the game.

17059.description: Forty-eight card deck rummy game in which each card has a factoid about the corresponding planet, sol, comet, or asteroids. Seven card hands, play to 100 points. Asteroids are wild. Unusual mechanism is use of comets to "crash" into one of an opponents cards placed face down. If a planet is hit, that card must be discarded.
17059.name: Space Rummy

17060.description:
From the box: "The dots on the dice determine how many rabbits jump, one after each other, from the back to the front. If there is an egg in one's supply, of the same color as that of the rabbit that ends up at the front once a jumping round has finished, the egg can be returned to the box.
With a little luck with the dice and some tactical thinking you will soon be able to return all their eggs.
For 2 - 4 players.
Two ideas for dice games, with a little bit of tactical thinking."

From the author of Galloping Pigs, this is a fun "jump-over" game aimed at the younger audience!
17060.name: Eierlei

17061.name: Combat Commander 1973-1983
17061.description: From the introduction: Combat Commander 1973-1983 is designed to simulate modern warfare, using military miniatures. Employing recently de-classified military information, the game sets up actual battlefield conditions, which allow one to reconstruct the military engagements of the 1970's, and to test most contemporary weapons and tactics on hypothetical conflict. Included are detailed rules governing: the use of armor, infantry and artillery; tactical air strikes and anti-air defense; electronic warfare and ECM; helicopter operations; precision guided munitions, such as anti-tank guided missiles, and tactical nuclear as well as chemical / biological weapons.

17062.name: Batman Begins: Shadow Assault
17062.description:
Ra's al Ghul, master of the League of Shadows, has sworn to destroy Gotham City! Racing through the night, Batman seems to appear in multiple locations at once, confusing his enemies with his speed and his stealth. But will that be enough? Can Batman stop Ra's al Ghul's ninja army before they activate their microwave cannon and wreak havoc upon the city?

One player is Ra's al Ghul and controls all the ninjas, the other players control the Batman figures. Both groups have different objectives.

Comes with: 4 Batman figures, 20 ninja figures, 1 board of Gotham City, 4 battle dice and power markers.

17063.name: Nick Game
17063.description:
Every agent chooses a secret nickname made up of equal number in words. In order to win players must guess the nickname of one of their opponents agents or kill everybody. In turn each agent must choose a movement (by foot, by car or by motorbike) an if they want to, an action (to catch, to shoot, to place a bomb, to be hidden, to try steal files). The actions allow you to get one letter of the nickname out of the victim and in some cases cause wounds.
The 16 parts of modular board allow you to make countless combinations for the city.
The game is set in an ideal city of 400 spaces.

17064.name: StarMarines
17064.description:
If you've ever been intrigued by that game of futuristic land combat by a company whose name rhymes with "Hames Nerkslop," but were put off by the cost of figures or the time and skill needed to paint them, this game might be just the ticket. Instead of expensive figures, you use free downloadable counters. Instead of a large gaming table filled with hand-made scenery, you use my M8 maps. If you want a bigger army or a larger map, just download another page and print it. Time-consuming movement and combat rules have been replaced with fast-playing hex-based rules. And all the occult stuff in the original game has been replaced with... nothing at all.

If you're unfamiliar with that game, the premise is straightforward: buy soldiers, vehicles and weapons with the build-points given to you, then fight an enemy of a different alien race. You can also "buy" experience or special skills for your troops, or add a Hero if you think he will help. Some races excel at crunching close combat, while some prefer a fast-moving style; some fight in low-tech swarms, and others prefer high-tech gadgets. Vehicles range from one-man scout bikes to hulking super-tanks. The size of the battle can be a squad of foot soldiers, or a company of 150-plus men with dozens of vehicles, or anything in between. Several basic scenarios are provided with the rules. Almost everything is definable.


StarMarines is a Free game based off of War Hammer 40,000

17065.name: Hack & Sack New Jersey
17065.description:
The Krylons invaded New Jersey one day. They had nothing personal against the Garden State, but they wanted to conquer New York City so they’d have a place to park, and they needed a base of operations. The Jerseyites were annoyed enough at being invaded. But being told that their state was just a stepping stone to New York was the last straw. As one, they rose up to fight for their homeland.

They didn’t have much to fight with. The federal government refused to intervene, because the Krylons’ green cards were all in order. The National Guard could help, if they could mobilize in time. Some of the state’s more militant citizens needed no encouragement to take up arms against the alien invaders. And a mad scientist in Newark (every cheesy sci-fi story needs a mad scientist) figured out how to turn pleasure boats and junk cars into impromptu spacecraft. But the aliens had big advantages in firepower and mobility.

On the plus side, the Krylons didn’t bring much of their advanced technology to bear. Their code of honor forced them to fight at the level of their intended victims, and they turned to the New Jersey media to determine what that level should be. Luckily, the Krylons’ cable TV had been cut off due to a billing error; they could only get one channel on their TV sets, and that channel was running a barbarian-movie festival that day. So the alien spaceships began disgorging their equivalents of Cossacks and Roman legions, thinking them adequate for the task of subduing the Garden State.

Boy, were they in for a shock.

17066.description:
Clockwork Stomp is the first supplement for Kenzer & Company's acclaimed actual-size miniatures wargame, Fairy Meat.

Gnomes: Clockwork Stomp contains background information and rules for gnomes, all-new gnome and fairy weapons, special gnomic equipment, status cards and counters, and battle scenarios. Fully compatible with Fairy Meat, Clockwork Stomp is also self-standing game in itself, complete with all the gameplay rules you'll need to load up and march into battle against other wee folk!

Slow, weak, and plodding, gnomes make up for their physical shortcomings with deadly ordnance, sinister gizmos and swift trigger fingers. With weapons ranging from the simple Iron Pistol to the horrifying Chainkiller Autocannon, these bearded brains are certainly nothing to laugh at! And with the addition of a mechanical limb or two, even hand-to-hand problems can be overcome- with some small sacrifices...

The gnomes are joined in battle by their mechanical minions, the clockwork fairies. With a mechanical, propeller-driven body and a living fairy head, the gun-toting clock-fairies provide speedy support for their gnomic masters' field operations. Rules are also provided for Rogue Clocks, liberated Clockwork Fairies for use in your own Fairy warband!

Also included are rules for the magic-wrench-wielding gremlins (foes of anything with moving parts) and an array of gnomic equipment, including toxic Faecide Foggers, Pipe Bombs, and the short-lived Hatbots.

Expands:

Fairy Meat
17066.name: Fairy Meat: Clockwork Stomp

17067.name: Fairy Meat: Sugar and Vice
17067.description:
Sugar and Vice is the second supplement for Fairy Meat, Kenzer & Co.'s acclaimed 1:1 miniature game of cannibal fairy combat. Sugar & Vice introduces two new breeds of Wee Folk: the decadent Moon-Fairies and the vulgar Pixies!

Lunar descendants of the old Fae royalty, the Moon-Fairies share a common ancestry with the Glitters of Earth. Unlike their earthly cousins, they've progressed (or perhaps degenerated) into a glamorous Rock & Roll-loving fairy kingdom. All goes well until they decide to check up on the Earth they left behind so long ago, only to find their former subjects have become murderous, barbaric, and frighteningly powerful.

To cope with the power Fairy Meat gives the insubordinate "natives", the meat-intolerant Moons have developed a magical lip gloss known as Pink. Pink allows them to kiss dead fairies rather than eat them, vampirically soaking up the corpse's powerful fairy essences. This addictive cosmetic gives them a much-needed edge on the battlefield, but it carries a terrible price; with the deadly risk of Overkiss, every kiss might be your last...

Sugar and Vice includes:
Rules and background for musical Moon-Fairy bands, Pixie mercenaries & gangs, and reality-warping Glamour Chunks!
More weapons, Twinkle spells, wands , and (yes) magic items!
Tasty new full-color counters!

Sugar & Vice provides more equipment, troops, spells and game options to all Fairy Meat players, expanding the game while keeping gameplay as swift and bloody as you've come to expect.

Expands:

Fairy Meat

17068.name: Dogfaces in Space
17068.description: Dogfaces in Space is an individual-soldier-level space combat game for 2 players. Choose the size of your battle, then fight it out. This game can be seen as an extension of my space/land battle game, Orbital Battle.

17069.name: Can You Make It as a Backpacker?
17069.description:
Can you make it as a BACKPACKER? That's the challenge of a new adventure-filled board game that tells you if you’ve got what it takes to travel the world.

Do the Visa Run, find your accommodation, and then hit the bar but keep an eye on your bag! Discover the must-do traveling experiences and the pitfalls to avoid, see the sights and survive the rickety public transport - all whilst racing across six continents with your mates. The first to travel the world in one piece wins the game

Just like the real thing, you have to travel on a tight budget - but don’t worry, there are plenty of opportunities to work and even phone home to bag some extra cash from Mum and Dad! You'll realize how quickly your money runs out, learn about the scams, the transport, the toilets... It's as close as you can get to the real thing without the food poisoning.

Designed by Marcus Lane, an experienced traveler, the game offers a backpacking insight that is difficult to grasp from books alone. Marcus says, “When I was knocking back a home-made rocket fuel in a remote Asian village one day I realized what a fascinating yet surreal world I was traveling in. I had read books that touched on some of the real issues of backpacking but nothing came close to telling me the full story. I decided to find another way to teach people what they were in for. It's as close to a trial run as there can be. You'll see how challenging yet fun the experience can be as you travel around the world meeting lots of new people and consuming all sorts of strange foods.”

Can you make it as a BACKPACKER? is quite simply the fun way to learn how to plan a safe trip.

Great for gap year students, career break gappers or anyone who fancies a trip down memory lane. Contains a gameboard, 6 backpackers, 224 Visa Run cards, 156 Continent cards, a Foreign Embassy, a wedge of doofers (cash), a dice and rules.

No cockroaches included!

17070.description:
How closely do you see Eye to Eye with your friends? Draw a category card and write down three items, trying to match at least one other person for each item you write down. The person who matches the most answers with other players wins!

This version of the SimplyFun classic, is great for everyone in your family Ages 8 and up

Note: To play Eye to Eye Junior, you will need the original version of Eye To Eye.

Expands

Eye To Eye
17070.name: Eye to Eye Junior

17071.name: Caravans of Ahldarahd
17071.description:
From the publisher's website:

As the leader of a powerful merchant clan, you must carefully plan the trade routes that will bring wealth to your family. Build fleets and caravans to control commerce in key cities and vie for rights of passage to your rivals' islands.

Caravans of Ahldarahd is a boardgame set in a fantastic realm of desert kingdoms. Each player has a unique gameboard with a mix of advantages and disadvantages. As you plan your strategy, you must choose whether to secure monopolies in your own region or throw caution to the wind and deploy your traders to distant ports. Your deals with fellow players will ultimately determine your success or failure.

The resources you need to build your trading empire can only be acquired by the highest bid, so you must balance fast expansion with longterm planning. If you strike too soon, your control may be easy to challenge. But if you wait too long, the game could end before you're able to fulfill your plans.

In addition to resource and route management, players can bid for the favor of the mighty Shah, the zealous Eyes of Shamesh, and the mysterious Pirate Queen to secure special advantages. Meanwhile, each person's map can be invaded by any opponent controlling its Right of Passage card. The position of your allies changes from turn to turn, so those who ignore the political play can find themselves at a disadvantage.

17072.name: Moola Money
17072.description:
From the back of the box: "Hold on for non-stop flights, hilarious rendezvous and secret destinations. A Bizarre Chase, Jet Set pace, and a Twist of Fate!"

The first player to build a Swiss ATM account of $1,000,000 wins the game.

Players roll dice and move around the board, collecting and losing money. Sometimes they are forced to give all cash on hand to another player, but money can also be saved in ATM accounts. Specific spaces on the board allow for withdrawals and deposits to your account. Various cities around the world are represented on the board.

Re-implements:

Moolah

17073.name: Watten
17073.description:
A popular Bavarian card game involving elements of betting and bluffing, this game is easy to learn and fun to play, especially by 4 in partnerships. Played with 32-cards, a German pack is usually used (acorns, leaves, hearts, bells) but a French-suited pack (spades, hearts, diamonds, clubs) will do just as well. The game is a trick-taking one with an interesting mechanism used for selecting the trump suit. Furthermore, when playing towards tricks, in most cases one is not obliged to follow suit!

The game is often played in pubs in Bavaria, with the losers buying the drinks. A system of signaling to your partner using a code involving small facial movements is permitted. Your opponents may or may not notice these, and you may in any case be bluffing!

17074.name: Bacchus
17074.description:
From the box :

Quiz game about wine!

Bacchus is an educational game. This games was designed to be fun and at the same time teach wine-lovers more about the wonderful world of wine.
Remember: wine is not only an experience for the senses and the spirit but also a pleasure and a pastime.

17075.description:
From the publisher website :
"The Pharaoh Khufu and his descendants, Khafre and Menkaure, have commissioned three pyramids to be built. As an Egyptian pyramid builder in ancient Giza, you will try to construct the finest three pyramids using good quality stones and to fill the pyramids with as much treasure as possible. Your rivals may try to thwart you by sabotaging your pyramid with inferior stones, by demolishing your constructed levels or by releasing scarabs at your construction sites to scare away your workers. Perhaps you may need to do the same to your rivals so that your three pyramids will be the finest ones chosen by the Pharaohs for their after-life!"
17075.name: Giza

17076.name: Dead Slug
17076.description:
In Dead Slug, players roll five six-sided dice and, if they can build certain "shapes", continue to roll and accumulate points. It plays very much like many bar room dice games.

The game is available for free on the creator's site:
http://www.deadantgames.com/dead_slug.htm

17077.name: Risky Mgax
17077.description:
CCG published in Spain and designed for a popular kids TV show called "Club Megatrix".

This game consist in drawing cards from a deck. This cards represents different tests where you have to complete an embarrassing task (atrevimiento/dare to, yellow cards) or tell a secret about you (verdad/true , blue cards). Each card scores different points based on the difficulty of the test.

17078.name: Stops: American Edition
17078.description:
STOPS is an acronym for states, territories or provinces.
The STOPS AMERICAN EDITION has 51 STOPS (or 51 possible answers), the names of the 50 states and Washington, DC, all of which are printed directly on the colorful, dynamic game board. STOPS provides you with a clue, and you try to identify the STOP.

From an official report:

"The award-winning trivia game that is challenging without being frustrating. Featuring a variety of questions that vary in difficulty, STOPS© is a game that can be played by geography experts and novices at the same time. The questions range from obscure facts that might be more suited to Jeopardy, to easier fare about landmarks, capitals and more. Testers gave high marks to the design of the board, and the simple directions. Many of the teachers at the testing centers told us that they believed STOPS© would make a great tool in their classrooms."
THE NATIONAL PARENTING CENTER, 1998 Spring Report

17079.name: Stops: North American Edition
17079.description:
STOPS is an acronym for states, territories or provinces.
The STOPS NORTH AMERICAN EDITION game has 62 STOPS (or 62 possible answers), the names of the 50 states, the 10 provinces and two territories, all of which are printed directly on the colorful, dynamic game board. STOPS provides you with a clue, and you try to identify the STOP.

Blurb from reviewer:

"The award-winning trivia game that is challenging without being frustrating. Featuring a variety of questions that vary in difficulty, STOPS© is a game that can be played by geography experts and novices at the same time. The questions range from obscure facts that might be more suited to Jeopardy, to easier fare about landmarks, capitals and more. Testers gave high marks to the design of the board, and the simple directions. Many of the teachers at the testing centers told us that they believed STOPS© would make a great tool in their classrooms."
THE NATIONAL PARENTING CENTER, 1998 Spring Report

17080.name: Colledge
17080.description: Colledge is a drinking/party board game for coed players, aged 21 and over (due to adult themes and alcohol). The object of the game is to reach the top of the board and graduate from college first. When players land on certain squares, they must draw cards, collect money, or make rules that must be followed by the other players. "Spell cards" require players to do such things as have phone sex, fake an orgasm, and spend time in a closet with another player. "Challenge cards" involve activities such as trivia questions, arithmetic, playing quarters, arm wrestling, and drinking. According to the Justintime website, Colledge gets players "laughing, drinking and hooking up."

17081.name: Tracer 2
17081.description:
Translated from the game rule:

Welcome to the world of Tracer. In this game you and your opponent play the roles of highly intelligent Tracers. Your mission is to mine for hidden treasures in four mountains swifter than your competitor. During the process you will test each other's memory, judgment, luck, as well as the calmness of discovering a vein of mineral. Only the sliest will prevail.

Game Content (54 Cards):

43 Action Cards (12 kinds)
4 Legendary Tracers
7 Mineral Vines (Including Archaeological Treasure)

Re-implemented by:

Montanara

17082.description:
Expansion of the Steam and Steel system to allow up to 8 player or additional counter for 4 players. Also has a few new units, battle board and rules on elite units. Requires the original game

Contains
Rules sheet
Battle board
4 sheets of counters
Extra money

Expands:

Steam and Steel
17082.name: Steam  and Steel: Expansion Set 1

17083.name: Get Sparta
17083.description: Get Sparta simulates the battle between the great power in the late Hoplite period. Generalship cards, special abilities and omens will influence the outcome of a battle.

17084.name: EasyStar
17084.description:
Game Scenario: there are two space empires that don't like each other, and their starships fight whenever they meet. Okay, so it's not very profound; whaddya want from a free game?

EasyStar is a 2-to-4-player tactical starship combat game that allows you great flexibility in designing your spaceships, without having to print out or erase worksheets for your ships every time you play. It does this with a system of track charts and counters. All you need to provide is one or two six-sided dice. The emphasis is on fast play and blowing things up, not on long, drawn-out slug fests. I created this game because I wanted unlimited variety in ship design and tactics, without getting bogged down in range measurements, turning angles, power factors, or checking off gazillions of ship-damage boxes. Game features include:


Reusable track sheets for ship design and keeping score
Up to 18 ships for each player
Five different sizes of starship, from very small to excessively big
Speed and weapons capacity for each ship type can be altered
All weapons can be custom-fitted for range and power
Beams, missiles, torpedoes, and point-defense weapons
Auxiliary devices including ECM, enhanced targeting, and deflector shields
Carriers with two kinds of fighters
Special advantages for each player's flagship
Movement rules including simplified inertia & momentum
Quick combat resolution - usually 1 die roll per weapon
Critical hits
Ramming attacks and accidental collisions
Optional rules for three-player and four-player games and campaign games

17085.name: S.L.O.B.S. III
17085.description:
The Simple Large Outer-space Battle System lets you fight very big space battles. If 42 ships and 12 fighters isn't a big enough battle for you, then print more sheets of counters and double your fleet, or triple it, or quadruple it, even! There is no record-keeping at all; the emphasis is on fast play and interstellar mayhem.

S.L.O.B.S. III is a complete game, with maps and counters. All you provide is two 6-sided dice.

17086.name: Gunfir(E)
17086.description:
The Generically-Useful Naval Force Interaction Rules (Easy) is a naval war game for people who like their games simple, or for people who want to fight big naval battles without getting bogged down in details. The era is the first half of the 20th century.

GUNFIR(E) assumes you have some of my All the Ships counters, or a set of 1:6000 naval miniatures. You'll also need maps, as described under "Setting Up a Battle." All you provide is one 20-sided and two 6-sided dice.

17087.name: EasyShips
17087.description:
My All the Ships project is as close as it probably will ever get to its goal: to portray every major combat ship in the world, from the late 1890's to the end of WWII, as a free downloadable counter. So far, there are over 6000 ships represented, not counting aircraft. One thing that I didn't include is a set of rules, since I figured that most naval-game buffs already have a rule set in mind, and are using my counters to beat the cost of ship miniatures. But all the rules I've seen are too complex for my taste, which means I can't play a game with my own counters. So, just for the heck of it, here are some simple rules for naval engagements.

Easy Ships assumes you have some of my All the Ships counters, although a set of naval miniatures could work. You'll also need hex maps of open sea, like the "Open Sea" map tile that comes with this game (which is from from my M8 map system). These rules are meant for simplicity and fast play, not for extreme realism. The rules emphasize surface combat. The intended era is the first half of the 20th century. All you provide is some 6-sided dice, and pens and paper for some simple record-keeping if you use carriers or submarines.

17088.name: Might of Arms
17088.description:
Might of Arms is a set of rules for battles using miniature figures for armies ranging from the stone age through to the 15th century AD. It focuses on large-scale battles rather than small unit actions.

MoA is a 108-page rulebook of which the last 40-odd pages consists of army lists. It is aimed at 15mm gaming, but has options for 25mm and 6mm (1:300 scale).

17089.name: Flashpoint!
17089.description: Flashpoint! is a rule book aimed at 25mm squad level combat. The 200 page rulebook contains not only the rules to play, but also weapons specifications, troop types, body armor, accessories, mechanized units and robots. Flashpoint! is set on Earth in the far future (2247), its background is a cyberpunk environment with cartels fighting each other. Players spend share points building up their units before going into battle.

17090.name: Ax Your Tax
17090.description: Endorsed by Howard Jarvis, author of California's "Proposition 13" tax code change in the late 1970s. Object of the game is to "become a TAX LOOPHOLE EXPERT" and thus gain the most money.

17091.name: Challenge the IRS
17091.description: Players compete at finding deductions while avoiding criminal and civil fraud charges - and jail time - during the audit cycle. Deductions can be challenged by the I.R.S., or the other players. As noted on the box, the object of the game is "to claim every possible deduction and end up as the taxpayer with the largest refund."

17092.name: Tax Evasion
17092.description: Players go around the board 12 times making investments, finding (and buying or selling) tax loopholes, shunting funds off to their Swiss Bank Accounts, and - of course - paying taxes. At the end of the game each player fills out a final Tax Form. The player with the greatest Net Worth is the winner.

17093.description: Samurai wargame rules is a lightweight set of rules focusing on 25mm squad-level combat from 1100AD to 1500AD in Japan where a single figure represents a single man with its own unique fighting ability. Samurai wargame rules simulates the skirmishes between the private armies of rival Daimyos. It is an 18 page stapled rulebook.
17093.name: Samurai Wargame Rules

17094.description:
A desktop strategic game on the Seven Year War in America.

13"x19" map

112 counters
17094.name: Montcalm & Wolfe

17095.name: Starhound
17095.description:
Starhound is a set of rules for simulating fighter to fighter deep space combat using miniatures. The rulebook consists of 21 pages and a single reference sheet made from card.

The rules present both a basic as well as an advanced game, with the advanced game adding homing missiles and crew experience into the mix.

17096.name: Plunder
17096.description:
Plunder is a vintage game with spiffy metal ships and metal coins, marred only by somewhat fuzzy rules.

Players take on the role of pirate ships and merchantmen in a race for the Treasure at the end of the board. Merchantmen pay tribute into the Treasure when they land on orange spaces; pirates pay when they land on green spaces. Players can take 5 Pieces of Eight as ransom out of the Treasure when they land on a Free Spot. They may also opt to pay any ship that passes them 3 Pieces of Eight or retreat their ship to the designated retreat point for that leg of the board.

When one player reaches the Treasure space by exact count, that player collects the Pieces of Eight and Doubloons amassed in the Treasure. One assumes that the game ends at this point and the player with the most value in coins is the winner, but the rules do not explicitly state this.

17097.name: England Expects
17097.description: "England Expects" is a rare, "vintage" Card Game with a British Royal Navy theme published by Pepys around 1940. It features beautifully illustrated cards depicting a variety of British military navy scenes, backed by a picture of Nelson's column.

17098.name: Challenger 2000
17098.description:
Challenger 2000 is a rulebook focusing on modern warfare from 1970 up to 1995. It is at 6mm (1:300) scale and focuses on battle groups (company level). It introduces rules for new weapons and equipment, such as Explosive Reactive Armour, modified missiles to deal with it, countermeasures (including anti-missile systems) and sensors.

Major changes from Challenger II to Challenger 2000 include:
a) A new move sequence.
b) Area fire is treated as a combined firefight rather than a number of individual elements firing.
c) A new morale system based on sub-units.

Products Published by Tabletop Games for Modern Warfare Rules
Wargames Research Group 1950-1985 Rules for Armoured Warfare
Not actually a Challenger Expansion
1980 Ultra Modern Army Lists and Organisations
1982 Ultra Modern Army Lists and Organisations Second Edition

1982 Challenger (1st Edition)
1983 Challenger Revised Edition

1984 Battlezones - Scenarios for the Ultra Modern Period

1985 Ultra Modern Army Lists and Organistation Volume 1
The Central Front
Nato Warpac
European Neutrals

1985 Utlra Modern Army Lists & Organisation Volume 2
Middle East
Africa
Far East
Latin America
Intervention Forces

1986 Digest No. 3 - Challenger / Corps Commander
Engineering Equipment Data
Engineering Lists
Engineering Scenarios
Equipment Data Update
Army List Update
Challenger Rule Amendments
Challenger Close Assault Rules
Coprt Commander OMG Reinforcements
Armoured Recovery Vehicles
The Australian Army

1988 / 1989 Challenger II (Second Edition)

1989 Digest 4
Ultra Modern Army Lists for Challenger II Rules
The Central Front
NATO
Warpac
European Nuetrals

1989 Digest 5
Ultra Modern Army Lists for Challenger II Ruels
Middle East
Africa
Far East
Latin America
Intervention Forces

1989 Modern Aircraft Handbook - Aircaraft Details & Weapons for Challenger II
1992 Revised Modern Aircraft Handbook - Aircraft Details & Weapons for Challenger II (Ammendments + Challenger 2000 Modificaions).

1992
Challenger 2000 (Third Edition)
1994 Challenger 2000 Modern Equipment Second Edition Part One
1998 Challanger 2000 Modern Equipment Second Edition Part Two

17099.description:
From the Publisher:

Secure your civilization's place in the annals of history, build wonders that will dazzle the hearts of men, build a commercial empire, take charge of the battle fields, launch your ships across the Mediterranean so that they carry to all the world the might and grandeur of your economic, cultural, and military power!

The Mythology Expansion for Mare Nostrum introduces several new elements into the game, such as the addition of a sixth player who represents the fabled civilization of Atlantis.

A new map is added depicting western Europe beyond the Pillars of Hercules and the island of Atlantis. You can pray to the Gods and engage fierce mythological creatures to aid you in your conquests. The more you play, the more new facets to the game you will discover, each more interesting than the last. The world of Mythology is so engrossing that once you enter this ancient realm, you will want to prove, once and for all, that the Mare Nostrum is and always will be Your Sea!

In the Mythology Expansion, you will be able to discover and explore:


New people, Atlantians, allowing you to play with 6 players.
Old Gods (Poseidon, Mars, Isis, and more).
A game board that extends the basic map to the west and includes Atlantis, the Iberian peninsula, Gaul, and North Africa
Over twenty new heroes (Achilles, Gilgamesh, Minos, Spartacus, and others)
Six Mythological creatures (the Phoenix, the Kraken, Centaurs, Behemoths, and more).
Pottery - the thirteenth resource!


Expands:

Mare Nostrum
17099.name: Mare Nostrum: Mythology Expansion

17100.name: Words! Words!
17100.description:
Words! Words! is a challenging and exciting word game for family and friends. The erasable game board makes for quick clean up and unlimited hours of repeat play.

Players select a card from the pile which provides one of a variety of categories; people, geography, sports, music, places, and things. Points are scored by printing words which identify with the category on the card selected. The player with the highest score wins the game!

Words! Words! It's challenging, yet easy to learn. It's fun and educational too!

17101.name: Postie Game
17101.description:
The scene, a small town. You are a local Postie, with your daily assortment of mail to deliver hustling from call to call despite the few minor set backs you may stumble across. You prod onward, only to encounter more obstacles. Even these cannot dampen your spirits. But you have one fear, a constant threat to your well being and your ability to complete you deliveries "The Family Dog". Waiting to defend its personal domain. Once the mail has been successfully delivered, you must return to the Post Office before you fellow Posties. But beware of the 'Loose Dog'....

Postie is a game that delivers excitement, suspense, hours of fun, and the mail.

As you enter the world of the Postie; an occupations filled with adverse weather conditions, perils of walking over all kinds of terrain and that age old enemy of the Postie, the dog. Postie is a game of luck and strategy in equal amounts. No attempt had been made as they become familiar with the game. Postie is not difficult to play.

So pick up your mail, sling that mail bag over your shoulder, hit the streets and be careful out there.

17102.description:
War in the West is a corps/division level simulation designed to recreate these massive battles. Each hex represents 33 kilometers of actual distance andd each game-turn represents one week of actual time (the same scale as War in the East).

There are 5 scenarios: Poland, France 1940, North Africa, Italy and France 1944. In addition the scenarios can be used as a starting point for a campaign scenario coving the remainder of the war.

Part of WAR IN EUROPE, but also sold separately.
17102.name: War in the West

17103.name: Calypso
17103.description: A partnership card game that each player uses the cards won in tricks to form calypsos (all 13 cards of a the players given suit) for herself and her partner. Four regular decks are shuffled together but only 52 are used each hand. Each player has her own trump each hand.

17104.description:
The game of Canasta is said to have originated in Montevideo, Uruguay, around 1940. From there it spread to Argentina, the USA and throughout the world. It was extremely fashionable in the 1950's, threatening for a while to displace Contract Bridge as the premier card game.

The rules were standardized in North America around 1950 and it was this version of the game that gained worldwide popularity. In many countries, Canasta is still played in more or less its original form, sometimes alongside a number of variations. In North America, however, the game of Canasta has continued to develop, and the version now favored by many American players, called Modern American Canasta, is very different from the classic game.

Canasta is generally agreed to be best for four players, playing in partnerships. However, there are playable versions for two, three or six players.

Canasta is a standard deck playing card game modified by adding two decks together and adding all four Jokers.
17104.name: Canasta

17105.name: Thorough-Bucks
17105.description:
