Horse racing game using statistics from real horses to simulate a horse racing season. Players attempt to purchase a stable of horses and enter them in races of varying distances. Each horse is rated from 6 furlongs to 12 furlongs with a number from 15 (no races at that distance) to 36 (world record. Players then enter horses in events for prize money, as well as, all players get to bet on the races.
Building a stable is fun but betting right will win you the game.
Similar to a lot of the stat based sports games.

17106.description:
The game, which is known by many names and has been released in many versions, was invented in 1889 by the French mathematician François Edouard Anatole Lucas and first named La Pipopipette.

Boxes is a plasticised version of a game we used to call Dots and Dashes. In the paper and pencil version, you draw a grid of dots and then each player must alternately draw dashes joining adjacent vertical or horizontal dots. If you are able to complete a square, you mark it as your own and you must draw another dash. At the end of the game, players achieve long runs of squares. When all squares are claimed, the game ends, and the winner is the player with the most squares.

The grid of boxes is 8x9 in size for 72 positions to be captured.

Similar to:

Squares - but on a larger rectangular board.
Honeycomb (which uses a hex board)
Squaresville (with double scoring squares and premarked edges)
17106.name: Boxes

17107.name: Milleranagrams
17107.description:
A game in which players make words from a central pool of revealed letters. By making an anagram of other players words, or adding letters, words may be stolen. Designed by the charismatic but maybe slightly loony Professor Julius Sumner Miller who hosted a children's popular science TV show in the 1970s in Australia. Consider this section from the rule book:

"It is obvious that longer words are still scarcer and harder to "operate on". But - armed as we are with this advice - we have put together A GAME where - to put it briefly - we make words out of letters and other words out of the words already made. And although on the face of it the scheme of things may appear trivial the fact is that this GAME can be made to possess and demand an uncommon intellectual gymnastic."

17108.name: Arclight
17108.description:
From the publisher:

Premiering at the Origins Game Fair, Arclight is a fast playing spaceship combat game. This new release from Second Rat Games captures all the fury and chaos that dogfighting in space promises. With a one roll resolution system, an evolving setting, and the ability to add your own empire to the official universe, Arclight promises to be an excellent addition to any fighter jocks collection. Everyone wants to blow stuff up, and Arclight satisfies in style.

17109.description:
Fall of Constantinople was published in Panzerschreck Magazine #6 (Summer, 2001). The game consists of an 8.5 x 11 inch map, several dozen colorful but unmounted counters, and twelve pages of rules. The rules include many examples of play, several optional rules (among them two-player possibilities), and designer notes.

From the introduction:
Fall of Constantinople is a solitaire game about the climatic battle, following weeks of assaults and bombardments, that occurred during the great siege of 1453. The gamer commands the Ottoman Turks, and the system plays the Byzantine Christian defenders.

Can YOU create the decisive breakthrough needed to overcome the wearied defenders of Constantinople? Or will your siege be lifted once and for all? Play Fall of Constantinople and find out for yourself!
17109.name: Fall of Constantinople

17110.name: The Gospel of John: Family Board Game
17110.description:
The Gospel of John: Family Board Game is based loosely on the motion picture of the same name, although the majority of the information (and hence the game play) comes primarily from Gospel of John (found in the Christian scripture).

Players take turns moving pawns around a board following a Jesus pawn, answering trivia and performing tasks, with the goal of having the most scoring tokens when Jesus completes his journey.

17111.name: Unispel
17111.description:
This game was made for the company Unilever.

Object of the game is to collect the most points by making rows of four or more by placing pieces of the same color on the board.

All players have seven pieces to pick from and after placement of the pieces, you fill your hand up to seven again.

A lot of products of Unilever are mentioned in this game.

17112.name: Weerwijzer
17112.description: It is a quiz. Who Knows the Most of the weather and has the right answers to the difficult questions.

17113.name: Wie doet de Afwas?
17113.description: Play cards or stack them on other players stacks and clear your hand. whoever does this first wins and does not have to do the dishes...

17114.name: I've Never... The Outrageous Game of Truth
17114.description:
"I've Never...? The Game of Truth" is an adult party and drinking game similar to Truth or Dare in which people reveal what they have and haven't done in their lives. Players move around the board and perform various actions such as taking drinks, giving drinks, dancing, singing, and spinning in a circle. Players move their pieces by answering "I've never..." cards-- for example, "I've never had sex in a hot tub." If the player answers "true" he or she may be able to move forward or give someone a drink. If "false," the player may have to take a drink or do something silly, such as sing a nursery rhyme.

Game contents include game board, game rules, dice, 8 Playing Pieces, 100 I've Never…? questions (including 10 blank Make Up Your Own cards). This game is intended for people aged 21 and older.

17115.name: Borodino
17115.description:
A French wargame on the battle of Borodino.

18 turns of 45mn

220 counters

A 60x80cm map

17116.name: Stratastar
17116.description:
From the publisher:

Space Empire building, Interstellar conquest.
Build, maneuver, trade, and fight your way to Galactic supremacy.
Minimal units and card mechanics make for quick turns.

Rules are available free for download at http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/SStar.html

Components must be printed & cut out prior to play.

17118.description:
Highly complex early European mathematical abstract game which illustrates the number theory of Boëthius. Played by intellectuals and mathematicians between the 10th and 16th centuries and used as a mathematical teaching method.
Rules varied considerably. Rivaled Chess as the premier intellectual game during its heyday.

In 1985, a "modern" game variant basing on the base elements, called Rythmo, was published.

Online Play


Boardspace.net (real-time, AI option)
17118.name: Rithmomachy

17119.description:
This 2-player game gives a good, fun introduction to Poker without stress about betting or bluffing. The rules give 5 variations of play, such as simply drawing one card and playing it, or drawing two, choosing one to play on your side and giving your opponent the other and so on. A die is rolled to determine how each hand will be played. The game is played in 3 rounds, and 3-5 cards are turned up at the start of each round and get $200 in chips placed on them. Players take turns to lay up to 4 more cards on their side, to make the best 5 card hand they can. In this way, the original face-up card on each row is shared by the players, and you can easily see what you need to play to beat your opponent's hand.

When the rows are complete, the winning hand on each row takes the chips in the middle. After playing the simple version, players can then use the betting rules, which let them raise the betting on the center cards. This makes the game more tense and more fun as the stakes are raised. Can you play the right card to beat your opponent and win $100s?

The game components are: a game board, a small card deck, plastic chips, and a d6.






From the publisher's description:
Head-to-Head Poker Game Parker Brothers and Hasbro Games.
Build the best hand in this poker duel! Six different games in one!

Experience hand-to-hand combat- poker style! You and your opponent duel it out as you play cards on your respective sides of the board, sharing the common cards between you. But watch out! Each game has its own surprises and you could end up empty-handed. Build the strongest combinations on the board and take the chips to win!
2 adult players.
17119.name: Head-to-Head Poker

17123.name: 4: The After Dinner Golf Game with Attitude
17123.description:
4 is a game of no-holes barred golf for golf fanatics and golf widows, novices and non-believers.

To succeed at 4 you must be-friend mother nature, dodge the course officials, keep you head well down, your cards well up and blatantly disrupt your opponents at every opportunity.

Card based game.

17124.name: The Driving Test
17124.description:
The Game that helps you pass your test.

The Driving Test has been developed in association with The Driving Standards Agency - the official body that sets all driving examinations and tests all learner drivers. So, every time you play it you will learn more of the theory of driving and road safety - essential if you are going to get rid of those big red 'L' plates.

17125.name: Ars Mysteriorum
17125.description:
In Ars Mysteriorum, each player participates in King Florim's Alchemy Apprentice Competition. As an apprentice, you will vie to see who can earn the most money by the end of the competition. You will barter favors for basic elements such as Brimstone, Verdigris, and Salt. You will use those elements not only to gain entrance into Masters' tents but to demonstrate to the Masters your ability to successfully complete a recipe. For an alchemist, they are simple recipes like turning lead into gold or sand into rubies. As you complete the recipes, they are added to your Recipe Book, and you are paid at the end of each day for the best combinations of recipes. When the competition is over, the apprentice with the most money will be declared a new Master Alchemist.

(From the publisher's description.)

17126.description:
Another multi-player Sengoku Era game, something like a paired down version of Feudal Lords.

Published by Sho Kikaku in 1991.
17126.name: Eiyu Sengoku Jidai

17127.name: Sekigahara fierce fight
17127.description:
Tactical level wargame for battle of Sekigahara in Sengoku period of Japanese history.
Gekitoh Sekigahara is means fierce fight in Sekigahara.

Each unit represent 400 soldiers. Some unit represent major lord or generals and his personal soldiers.

Players control either Eastern army(Tokugawa) or Western army(Ishida and Mori). Each army consist of many clans. Each clan composed by a lord, generals and soldiers.

In each turn, there are opponent's defensive fire step between movement and combat step.
There are two types of combat, fire fight and melee , in both case, basic combat result is morale check. So most important ability of unit is morale.
Not only undermine the troops of their clan, the loss of the lord also decreases army morale. Reduction of army morale reduces the combat effectiveness of the whole army.

The game include seven scenarios, two historical and five hypothetical situation.
Winner determined by elimination of opponent's highest lord or victory points based on elimination of units.

17128.name: Coffee Break
17128.description:
From the back of box:

"In Coffee Break, challenge your co-workers to a contest of time management, competing to take the most coffee breaks during a day of work. To win, work hard and avoid goofing off, being sure to stay one step ahead of the boss.

So relax, grab a cup of coffee and experience a whole new kind of coffee break. And if people complain, remind them that its all in a day's work."

Game includes:
a game board
50 cards
40 coffee break markers
5 pawns
rules
a Coffee Break mug

Players take turns drawing and playing cards to move pawn ahead on the board which is divided into the hours of the work day. Players have the option of playing a card or taking a "coffee break" and sitting for a turn while collecting a chit. Cards can move a player forwards or move back another player. Every turn the Boss is moved one space. If the Boss catches up with you you lose a coffee break. Player to reach the end of the work day with the most coffee breaks wins.

Game only available from website www.gluckgames.com

17129.description:
From the website:
"Your fleet has just deployed out of N-Space™ into enemy territory, only to find they are outmaneuvered! Dogfight back to your Home Quadrant, and then count off into your Mothership before they get 'Gammon you! You can play with the standard ships below, OR you can use any of the ships offered for my Trekkers:Genocide ™ game."

The set includes a 3/8" thick by 16" round board, 2 Fleets of 15 pewter cast ships, Rules, 2 dice, and a cloth bag.
17129.name: Battlegammon

17130.description:
The Commodores Game is an advanced rule set for Plunder. Plunder's Commodores Game is for those with a true pirate and gamers heart.

The Commodores expansion for Plunder is designed to increase the total number of maximum players from 4 to 6. It also includes additional rules that make the game more complex and even more exciting than the base game. In order to play the Commodores Game you will need a copy of Plunder and to down load and print the Commodore Expansion.

The Commodores expansion is a free PDF download from the games fan club website (www.plunderfanclub.com). The PDF downloads include additional Captain mats and ships for two new colors (Black and Silver), new rules sheet, and additional national flags, coins, and cargo counter sheets.

Expands:

Plunder
17130.name: Plunder: The Commodore's Game

17131.description:
Matching and pantomime game for young children based on the book of the same name.

"Find the matching cards for your game board, while imitating the motions on the cards. When all the boards are completed everyone wins!"
17131.name: Guess How Much I Love You Game

17132.description:
A mini 18xx game, set in Colorado, and appearing in issue #17 of Rail Gamer Magazine. It's for either two or three players, and there are only nine playable hexes, so it's extremely "mini". The two player game has 2 corporations, and the 3 player game has 3.

There is an interesting bond mechanism that allows directors more control over how much money gets into the company.

boardgamehonor.8859: 2006 Golden Geek Best Family Board Game Nominee

17133.description:
Railways of the World (2009) is the new edition of the base game for Eagle Games' popular Railways of the World series, first published as Railroad Tycoon in 2005. It reimplements the original game with several improvements.

Revisit the early days of the Age of Steam as you begin with a locomotive (the venerable John Bull, the first locomotive to run in North America) and a vision (your Tycoon "mission" card). From there, build your budding railroad network into a vast empire. Connect New York to Chicago, earn the most money, develop bigger and faster locomotives and maybe even span North America and build the Transcontinental Railway!

Multiple expansions featuring different maps are available. Railways of the World is the new base game for the system and includes the engine placards, railroad tiles, train tokens, money, bonds, and other items that are needed in almost all the Railways of the World series. A gameboard depicting the eastern half of the United States is included in the base game, as well as a mounted map of Mexico.

This game is preceded by the designer's other Winsome train games: Age of Steam, Australian Railways, Volldampf, New England Railways, Veld Spoorweg, Lancashire Railways, and Ferrocarriles Pampas. Railroad Tycoon was the result of a collaboration with Glenn Drover, in which the mechanics and game-play of Martin Wallace's Age of Steam were simplified and streamlined and attractive over-produced components were added, in order to make Railroad Tycoon more appealing to less hardcore gamers and more accessible to a wider audience.

A revised reprint was published at the end of 2010 which made some component improvements, such as the addition of Railroad Operation cards for the Mexico map.

Complete series overview - The Railways of the World Series: Introducing the family members of the ideal medium-weight train game

Note: The RailRoad Tycoon board itself is gigantic (about 36x45 inches, 91x114 cm) and requires a huge table or playing on the floor.

Similar to:

Steam
17133.name: Railways of the World

17134.name: London Rules Wargames Section American Civil War 1863c
17134.description: Based upon an 'article submission' within the pages of "Miniature Warfare" Magazine Vol. 1 #-7, and part of a 'Series' for "Miniatures Wargaming". This 'Booklet' has a YELLOW 'front & back' plasticized-'looking' outside covers, with BLACK print on the front and plastic 'binding' for the pages. It contains '20'-pages of RULES in a 'half-page'~SIZED format, and covers the 'Basics' of "minis gaming" within this. It details the use of 'BOUNDS'~written 'Orders' and simultaneously revealing them, for its 'mechanism' of PLAY. You will NEED to provide *SPECIAL* 6-sided-'DICE' numbered as follows: " 2, 3, 3, 4, 4, 5 ", as well as some regular 'D-6's, various other 'sundry' items associated with this 'genre' as required, and some 'Markers' of the same SIZE as the 'Units' that they will represent in the 'Game'. These 'Markers' can even be 'used' for DECOY 'Units' where applicable, and you would have to obtain additional DATA on 'specifics' for individual 'Battles, Troops, & Leaders' prior to commencing PLAY for this. Calculations for creating 'Casualties' are based upon a 'percentages' and "DIE rolls" method being employed for resolving 'Conflicts'. These seem to be the 'easiest' and 'quickest' RULES devised at the time, for recreating the many epic "Confrontations" that were to 'define' the "American WAR for Reunification!" in the 'period' covered by this 'Rules SET'.

17135.name: Robots! The Game
17135.description:
Who left the Robot Factory door open? The robots are running away with all of the spare parts! Catch the robots and all of the missing pieces. Build your own robot to win the game.

2005 Creative Child Magazine Seal of Excellence

17136.description:
The ancient game of secret symbols is a classic strategy game with hidden mysteries as old as the pyramids! Take turns placing shapes on the board to reveal 9 different patterns. The more complex the design, the more points you score.

2005 Mensa Select

Integrates with

DaVinci's Challenge Card Game
17136.name: DaVinci's Challenge

17137.name: Maya & Miguel Word Scramble
17137.description: Race to spell a word before time runs out. Spell words in English or Spanish and score points for the number of letters used.

17138.name: Allo Allo
17138.description:
The 'Allo 'Allo board game was made for the BBC by Powage Press in 1989. It is based on the very popular BBC sitcom of the same name set in a cafe in occupied France in WW2.

Players can choose to be in the French Resistance or a member of the occupying German army.

The objective for French resistance player(s) is to try to find the English RAF airman "Carstairs" and "Fairfax" and get them across the border without being captured. The German player(s) have to capture them.

Game Contents:
Game Board
6 Character Pieces
100 Cards
2 Dice
Instructions.

17139.name: Double your Money
17139.description:
Double Your Money is a board game from the 1950's, produced by Bell games and based on the very successful UK ITV game show of the same name hosted by Hughie Green.

The board has 4 distinct triangles. Each triangle reflects the player's colour - Green, Red, Blue or Yellow. Each player place themselves at the start of their chosen colour. No two players can be in the same triangle. Movement is decided by the spinner in the centre of the board. A player moves along each row of their triangle. If a player's piece lands on the same colour square as his colour, he is asked a question. If he is right, he places his marker to the side of his triangle in the first prize money of 1 pound. Next time he gets a question right, he will double his money i.e. a progression of 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, etc. (except when the prize money gets to 256 pounds, when it next jumps to 500 pounds so that the prize money could stop at 1,000 pounds.
The first player to gain the prize of 1,000 pounds is the winner.

The TV show, in its day, was extremely popular. Anyone winning the thousand pound prize was a celebrity (it didn't happen a lot). A thousand pounds, in the austerity of 1950's Britain, was a great deal of money.

17140.name: Hunt the Hole
17140.description:
A fast memory game for 2 or more players.

The goal is to stick rods into empty holes of a wooden block.

Each player takes his turn to stick one of the rods in a hole not yet taken. When he hits a hole already taken, he must put back the rod and is disqualified. Winner is the player who succeeds to find an empty hole in the end.

To make the game more challenging each player may turn the board in any direction after having completed his move.

17141.name: Every Second Counts
17141.description:
"Every Second Counts is a game of "Family fun that gives everyone a chance to shine" for 4 players Ages 10 and up

It was made in 1987 by Peter Pan and is based on the BBC Quiz Show of the same name which was hosted by magician Paul Daniels and which ran from 1986 to 1993 in the UK.

The box describes the game as follows:

"It's not just what you know - it's how quickly you can shout it out. Pit your WITS against the clock!"

17142.name: Hell by Starlight
17142.description: Hell by Starlight is a unique set of Science Fiction wargames rules designed for games in either 15mm or 25mm scales. Generic in nature, contains rules for hostile environments, electronic warfare, snipers, bio-weapons, AI, cavalry, medics and psionics, in addition to the usual mainframe of command, reaction, movement, morale, firing and casualties.

17143.description:
This is a reprint of the old Ironclads and Ether Flyers. Ironclads and Ether Flyers is a set of 19th Century Aeronaval miniatures rules. It focuses on battles between seafaring battleships and aerial gunboats and is set in the Space: 1889 universe.

The rule book covers not only combat rules, but also include scenarios as well as campaign rules. The rules detail aeronaval combat: movement, attacks, ramming and damage. Advanced rules address special weapons and vessels.
17143.name: Ironclads and Ether Flyers

17144.name: Barbarossa
17144.description:
The Emperor is dead. The throne is empty. The courts are out of order and power is in the hands of whoever holds the sword. Everybody asks: Who will be the new Emperor? Four kings claim the throne. Who will have it?

Barbarossa (translated to Redbeard) was the nickname of Emperor Friedrich I, who lived from 1123 to 1190. He was crowned as king in 1152, and Emperor in Rome in 1155.

The players take roles of medieval kings, trying to get rich by conquering cities and castles. Possession of cities and castles gives the right to claim taxes. Taxes are used to buy knights, squires and archers to protect the kings interests.

Before the game starts, the players agree on a playing time. Whoever is the richest (cash plus value of knights, squires and archers) by that time wins the game. In addition you can win by being the only player with a live king, or by having a certain numbers of cities and castles (2 players = 16, 3 players = 14, 4 players = 12).

There are rules for movement, which depends on the unit, and the terrain moving through. Combat, which depends on the units, and the defenders position. Tax collection, including the ability to bleed the peasants, and their possible revolt. Pillaging of cloisters, buying now units, and drawing a chance card at the end of each year.

Marketed as a family game, but rather complicated for that.

17145.name: Snake Snack
17145.description:
The game is played on board with 4 snakes biting each others tails. There are 11-14 spots on each snake. Players take turns rolling the die and moving one of their 4 counters. When your counter lands in front of a snakes mouth, all counters standing on a spot of the same color as the counters color, is eaten and out of the game. Last player with counters in the game wins.

Found in a book called: "John Astrop's Ghastly Games"

17146.description:
Rommel at Bay is an operational level simulation of the World War II Allied offensive in southern Tunisia which took place in mid-March 1943. Located here were the main Axis fortifications defending Tunisia, fortifications nearly as formidable as those at Alamein. Had the German-Italian army succeeded in defending, the war in North Africa would have been lengthened and perhaps Allied command would have changed again. The playing pieces represent the actual units which participated in the campaign and the map represents the actual terrain over which those units fought. Rommel at Bay is basically a two player game in which one player controls the Axis forces while his opponent controls the Allied forces.

The two players maneuver their units across the map and conduct combat according to the rules of play. Victory occurs and the game ends immediately when one player has achieved the conditions given in the scenario being played. The other player wins the game by preventing his opponent from achieving his victory conditions.

The game has two scenarios. The first (Medenine) is a smaller scenario of the battle that was fought March 6th to 8th 1943. The second scenario is the main Mareth Campaign March 20th to 28th.
17146.name: Rommel at Bay

17147.name: Blue Max: An Aces High Expansion
17147.description:
Blue Max is not a complete game in itself; it is an expansion kit for 3W's popular game Aces High, dealing with aerial combat during World War 1. Coverage of the Great War in the air is extended to cover Italy, Macedonia and Palestine, as well as the strategic bombing raids on Britain and Germany. Counters and data sheets are provided for 39 new types and variants of aircraft; over 20 new scenarios are provided which use these new aircraft as well as several types which were provided in the original game, but for which no scenario was given. Extra rules are provided extending the detailed coverage of the subject. The numbering of these rules has been kept. consistent with that of Aces High.

The reissued boxed version of Aces High incorporates the additional rules and planes of Blue Max: An Aces High Expansion within the box. However, Blue Max: An Aces High Expansion continued to be sold seperately as a stand-alone expansion.

Expands:

Aces High

17149.name: Silly Stories
17149.description:
From the box back.

Perfectly sensible sentences get wacky fast when they're scrambled into crazy combinations.

In an original twist on memory card games, kids flip story cards to hunt down the WHO, WHAT, and WHERE that combine to tell a Silly Story.

Simpler and more challenging ways to play give beginners and veteran players alike plenty of brain building fun.

Learning the Silly Stories way...

Pre-readers and early readers alike have fun while they practice their memory skills, word recognition, powers of observation and giggles.

17150.name: Economaze
17150.description:
A family game for 2 to 4 players, Ages 10 and up. Collect salaries and bonuses on every turn. Buy and sell stocks, CD's, gold coins, houses, and insurance to take advantage of good luck cards and avoid setbacks from bad luck cards. Exciting continuous player action, including gambling between players and between players and the bank.

In this game you are never so far behind that you cannot come back to win. Game elements permit rapid changes in standing whereby the losing player at mid-game can easily be the winner.

Teaches children how to manage investments relative to the real economic world in a manner that holds their interest. A strategic, challenging game for competitive adults. Realistic financial happenings spiced with the gambling mystique. (From the box bottom)

17151.description:
From the insert: "Middle East Combat is a titanic battle between Iraq, the USSR, Iran, Turkey, and Saudi Arabia for control of oil resources and key neutral nations, played with basic Axis & Allies rules."

Contents:
23"x30" bright full color folded map showing region names, oil areas, factories, and capitals(Heavy stock paper)
5 unit placement cards
Ten page rulebook which covers additional rules for
- neutral nation armies
- civil insurrections
- modern weapon technologies
- USSR special rules
- game balance adjustments
- short game scenarios
- map clarifications
- 10 questions and answers from the game

The Red Pact of USSR and Iraq form one side in this war and the Triad Nations of Iran, Turkey, and Saudi-Egypt form the other side.

Victory Conditions, 1) Hold ten oil areas at the end of a full turn, 2) Hold all enemy capitals, or 3) Hold a total of three neutral or enemy capitals.

Another use for your Axis & Allies game pieces.
17151.name: Middle East Combat

17152.name: Jo-Jotte
17152.description: Famous bridge personality Ely Culbertson's attempt to create an equally popular 2-person game. Jo-Jotte is named after Josephine Culbertson his first wife and distinguished partner. Unfortunately the game flopped and the couple divorced a year later. The game is basically Belote (i.e. Klobyash, Bella) with the addition of Notrump, a Nullo bid, Slam bid and also bridge-like scoring above and below the line.

17153.description:
From the publisher's website:

MOTOYAMA AIRFIELD #2, Iwo Jima, 27 February 1945: The Marines of Colonel Kenyon’s 9th Marine Regiment had a rough time during their first day in the line, 26 February. They had made two determined assaults on ‘Hill Peter’, to no avail. After reorganizing during the night, the 9th Marines were ready for another push to the top of the hill. At 1250 hrs., their break came. Following a ten minute preparation by division and corps artillery, both battalions struck out in a coordinated attack. With the 1st Battalion on the right and the 2nd on the left, the Marines began their move up the slopes of Hill Peter. The 1st Battalion overran the hill and continued on down the reverse slope and up to the crest of ‘Hill Oboe’ to the northwest. The 1st Battalion’s ‘A’ Company did not enjoy the same momentum on their way to Oboe. ‘A’ Company was stopped by a small enemy AA detachment with supporting fire from emplaced machine-guns in a small draw on their right flank. ‘A’ Company rapidly deployed to meet this threat.

ATS SEMPER FI! (aka Uncommon Valor Upgrade Edition) is the new COMPLETE GAME that depicts the battle for Iwo Jima. Three years into the Pacific war the United States Marine Corps had mastered the art of the amphibious landing. The landing force at Iwo still had much to learn about the enemy. Senior intelligence officers did not know until 27 February that General Kuribayashi was in fact personally running the show from his headquarters on Iwo Jima. As the Marines regrouped after their landing, it was obvious that something was different on Iwo Jima. No dense jungles, just ash from the island’s volcano, Suribachi. Steam could be seen rising from the natural sulfur water wells which bubbled to the surface all over the island. Worse, the dug-in defenders actually numbered half again the original estimate of 13,000. Kuribayshi was particularly pleased with the quality of his artillery and engineering troops. The Japanese defenders waiting for the advance of the V Amphibious Corps were well armed and confident. The game depicts the confrontation at Motoyama Airfield #2, a war waged with the most vicious weapons available to the combatants, including flame-throwing ‘Zippo’ Shermans and Japanese heavy artillery. Everything is included to play!.
· A collection of 517 color, die-cut counters representing the USMC and Japanese combatants that fought in the battle;
· Six scenarios, ranging from small to large, that all play on the historical map;
· A 22 x 34 color map of the Motoyama #2 battlefield on heavyweight stock;
· A complete ATS system rulebook tailored specifically to the game;
· Six Play Aid Cards;
· Battlefield Walk around and Special Rules document (an ATS specialty!)
· A color cover sheet (perfect for your rules binder) and a snazzy ziploc bag to hold it all.
17153.name: Semper Fi! Uncommon Valor ATS Upgrade

17154.description:
From the publisher's website:

ITEM POCKET, OKINAWA, 20 April 1944: As the afternoon wore on with ‘G’ Company unable to release the Japanese grip on the Pocket, Lieutenant Colonel McDonough decided to send up ‘E’ Company. At 1350 hours the company commander, Captain George R. J. Weigand, was ordered to move up between the two ridges, then turn left, using Fox Ridge as cover. The goal of the onslaught was Ryan’s Ridge, or alternately the road cut west of Gusukuma. It was still assumed at that point that contact could be established with 1st Battalion. Weigand completed passing through Ryan’s left flank and attacked east toward the crest of Ryan’s Ridge, heading toward what the Company Commander thought would be a covered route to the top of the ridge. Weigand attacked in platoons, moving to the point with 3rd Platoon, under command of Technical Sergeant Ernest L. Shoeff. This platoon would find itself attacking alone, after a storm of enemy machine-gun and mortar fire forced the rest of the company to ground. Weigand, Shoeff, and two squads kept moving forward, using tombs at the foot of the hill for cover. Orders were communicated to Weigand by a runner: extend the line at all costs. The Captain and two men soon found themselves cut off from Shoeff and the remainder of the main body. For the rest of the afternoon the company commander was under constant fire and out of communications with everyone. After dark Weigand managed to make his way back to Fox Ridge and rejoin his company. His uniform was shot full of holes but Weigand returned uninjured.

ATS BLOOD & IRON is the new COMPLETE GAME that depicts the battle for Okinawa. The center of the Japanese resistance in the area lay in the “I” section of Target Area 7777, which came to be called “Item Pocket”—in military terminology I is called Item. The pocket was the hub of the enemy position; from it, like spokes on a giant wheel, extended four low ridges, separated from each other by ravines and rice paddies. Potter’s Ridge ran north from the hub, Charlie Ridge to the northeast, Gusukuma Ridge to the southeast, and Ryan Ridge to the southwest. Lying between Gusukuma and Charlie Ridges and sloping to the east was a cone-shaped hill called by the Americans “Brewer’s Hill.” A gulch ran along each side of the hill—Anderson’s Gulch on the north and Dead Horse Gulch on the south. Both ran in an easterly direction, crossing Route 1 at small bridges just north of Gusukuma. The ground was superbly suited for active defense. Typical Japanese positions were connected by tunnels along the sides and under the crests of the ridges; Ryan Ridge, in particular, was honeycombed with such defenses. From Item Pocket the enemy had excellent command both of the coastal areas to the north and west and the open land to the east where Route 1 ran north-south. The Japanese had long been aware of the defensive value of this position against either a beach landing on the northwest or an attack from the north. Months before the Americans landed, Japanese troops and Okinawan laborers were boring tunnels and establishing elaborate living quarters and aid stations. The area was held by two companies of the 21st Independent Infantry Battalion of the 64th Brigade, 62nd Division, supported by an antitank company, a machine gun company, and elements of antiaircraft, artillery, and mortar units. At least 600 Japanese occupied the Pocket, reinforced by several hundred Okinawans.
· A collection of 517 color, die-cut counters representing the US Army and Japanese combatants that fought in the battle;
· SIX scenarios, ranging in size from small to large, that play on the historical map;
· A 22 x 34 color map of the ITEM POCKET battlefield on heavyweight stock;
· A complete ATS system rulebook tailored specifically to the game;
· Six Play Aid Cards;
· Battlefield Walkaround and Special Rules document (an ATS specialty!)
· A color cover (perfect for your rules binder) and a snazzy ziplock bag to hold it all.
17154.name: ATS Blood & Iron

17155.name: The Dartmoor Game
17155.description:
"The Dartmoor game" was designed in collaboration with Dartmoor National Park Authority to help improve geographical knowledge of visitors to this National Park in the county of Devon in the UK.

The object of the game is to travel across Dartmoor landing on specific grid references, collect a "certificate" and then return to your home town.

Movement and points accumulation is through use of dice and answering questions along the way.

Two versions of the game can be played. In the Short Game, the winner is the first player home with a score of at least 100 points. For a longer game, everyone continues playing until the points cards run out, and at that point, the winner is the person with the highest score.

17157.name: Forbidden
17157.description:
From the publisher's website:

Mah Jongg meets Gin Rummy! Themed with Chinese zodiac imagery, this fast paced, set-making card game finds players battling to accumulate 200 points over several rounds of play! Use your Forbidden cards to stop your opponents or multiply your score. Watch out! If you're caught with them in your hand at the end of the round, you lose points. In Forbidden, the best cards are the most dangerous!

17158.description:
A card game where teams of two, three, or four try to use their cards to construct a dragon and get points before their opponents can steal the dragon from them to take the points for themselves.

The game design is by Margaret Weis, the artwork is by Tom Wham.

From FunAgain Games:
Things get very interesting when dragons celebrate! The magic gets so out-of-hand that it can take some time to sort things out. With luck, a swift eye, and good teamwork, these dancing dragons will leave the party with the same wings and tail they had when they came in.

Dancing Dragons is a non-collectible, team-based card game that is easy to learn and fun to play. The game is suitable for children, families, or those who refuse to grow up!
17158.name: Dancing Dragons

17159.name: Survivor: The Game
17159.description:
If you think you have what it takes to be a contestant on Survivor, this all-new party game brings the hit TV show from exotic locales around the world straight into your living room.

Like the show, players break into two tribes to compete from immunity in a variety of hilarious and daring challenges that can be performed around the home. You never know what talents you'll need to call upon to win immunity for your tribe and send your opponents to the ballot box to vote someone off the team.

There's no trivia component so players don't have to be experts on the show to get off the sidelines and into the game. It's fun, competitive and highly strategic as players outwit, outplay and outlast each other to become the ultimate Survivor.

Note: There may be items required for play not included in the game box.

Comes with over 250 challenge cards, ballots, pencils and ballot box.

17160.name: Sound Effects
17160.description:
Sound Effects

The CD guessing game

What is the sound of one hand clapping? That's one sound you won't be asked to identify while playing Sound Effects, a fun new game that has the whole family listening! You will, however, be required to identify 80 other sounds, including the sound of someone brushing their teeth, a skill saw, a pinball machine, a tree falling or a mosquito...after listening for only a few seconds. Fun for anyone aged 4 to 104, Sound Effects can be played at any level. Players determine beforehand the level of difficulty (the tracks get progressively hard to identify) and how long they'll get to hear the sound before they must write their answer down. Mix it up by hitting random play on your CD player or take it with you in the car.

Includes a CD of more than 80 sound effects, pencils and score pads.
Ages 4 and up, 2+ players

boardgamehonor.8854: 2006 Golden Geek Best Gamer's Board Game Nominee

17161.description:
A civilization building game has finally been created that clocks in under two hours. Tempus plays on a modular board with an array of landscapes on each land tile to ensure a different game every session. Each turn pushes players' technological advancements forward, starting from fire and ending in the modern age.

Players are constantly faced with tough choices to vie for technological superiority or better positioning on the game board. This game features a rubber-banding mechanic in technological upgrading, where players catch up to the leader's advances at the end of every turn and shoot forward to take advantage of any new technologies that are discovered. This keeps players constantly in check, while rewarding planning for the next turn by giving an edge-up.

Tempus showcases a simple diceless battle mechanic featuring a subtle fog of war with Idea cards. Each card is dual-purposed. Using a card for war means giving up extra abilities that the Idea cards can grant. Or you might just want to hold on to them to advance in technology.
17161.name: Tempus

17162.description:
A cooperative game for children. The players have to pick up all the cherries, before the crow can steal them from the tree. With good memory and a little bit of deduction, the game can be won, but if you forget which tiles have the crow on the other side, watch out! He'll eat all your cherries!

The board is integrated in the box and comes with the usual nice Haba pieces.
17162.name: The Little Orchard

17163.name: Magnetic State to State
17163.description:
Racing game to see who can go from their starting state to finishing state. Players pick state cards, then can either place them on the board, hold on to them (to mess with the other players), or ask for a state card the other players have to play on the board. Once a players states are connected from starting state to finish state, they win.

From the Publisher:

Magnetic States cling like magic to the USA
gameboard as player draw or ask any other player for any of the different " State " cards that
will link their starting and finishing states. Without even realizing it, children will learn state
capitals, landmarks, and basic geography of the United States.

17164.name: Micro Fleet: World War II
17164.description: This wargame is a part of the Micro Warfare Series covering World War II naval combat. It is a miniatures-style game that includes cardboard ship counters. The rules cover individual ship command/gunnery rules, as well as rules for aircraft, weather, specific critical systems hits, flooding, and ramming. Specific counters are included to fight the Battle of the River Plate (Graf Spee vs. Exeter, Achilles, & Ajax) and the Sinking of the Hood (Bismarck & Prinz Eugen vs. Hood & Prince of Wales).

17165.description:
This wargame is a part of the Micro Warfare Series covering battles between the Earth (and its galactic allies) and the Zoltan Empire. It is a miniatures-style game that includes cardboard unit counters. The rules include a variety of fantastic weapons, including vortex beams, pluton flares, inertia weapons, and the ever-popular defense screens. Specific counters are included to fight small-scale combats, including attacks on colonies and police forts.

Supplements:
Sci-Fi
TTG-MA-S01 Xylon Vikings
TTG-MA-S02 Time Warriors
TTG-MA-S03 Kripton
TTG-MA-S04 Star Pods
17165.name: Micro Sci-Fi

17166.description:
From Gaming report preview:

In the game, players have a stack of chips. Each chip has 0 to 6 clout points. Players have to make a stack 15 chips, while not spending more than a set amount of Clout on the stack. Players take turns throwing the chips into the play area, and depending on how they hit the table, the individual effects of each chip occur. Chips have stats, abilities, and powers that affect game play. Some of the powers and abilities include protection, poison, weaken, and the strengthening of other chips within a radius of where the chip lands. After the chips land on the table, players can decide to attack other player's chips. Further chip effects can come into play in these situations. For example, chips with the Taunt ability force attacking chips to attack them before any other chips. Chips are eliminated from the play area as play continues. After throwing and playing out all their chips, players count all their Clout still in the play area plus extra points for proximity to other chips. Whoever has the most Clout points wins.

Some chips are common, while others are unique, adding to the collectability factor. In addition, there are various "types" of chips including effects, characters, and bases, to name just a few. Where chips land on the table and how players throw will have a significant effect on how the game will play out. The chips are approximately the same weight and style as casino poker chips, not cardboard. Physical skill will be a factor in game play, so gamers can start practicing their chip tossing now with the poker chips they already own.

This is the first set in the Clout series of games.

boardgameversion.175504: Alderac English Centaurs vs. Goblins Edition

17166.name: Clout Fantasy

17167.description:
Double Some 'R' Set is a trick-taking game that uses a unique deck of 50 cards. The card suits are fractions (ex. 1/2, 10/12, 5/6, 3/8, etc.) with the mid-cards (6/12, 5/10) also being worth extra points.

Double Some'R'Set is best played with partners (like in Spades).

The object is to bid on how many points you and your partner will take. There are 24 available points, 12 from the available tricks and 12 from available points.

Bidding goes around the table once where the players bid for the two card blind. High bid takes the blind and decides which suit (fraction set) will be trump.

Like in many trick taking games, and if you make your hand, you get the points. If you do not, you are set, hence the name (as they say in the rules) Some "r" set.

See also:
Some'R'Set - 28 card version
17167.name: Double Some'R'Set

17168.name: Shopping Center Game
17168.description:
A Baby Boomer children's game celebrating the new-fangled suburban Shopping Center. A spin and move game where you visit different stores and the first player to buy 6 items and get back to the parking lot wins.

From the bottom of the spinner

The Game of SHOPPING CENTER - for 2,3 or 4 Players

OBJECT: To take one purchase card from each store as a player moves his shopping cart around the board

WINNER: The first player to go out with six different purchase cards. Players take turns spinning and moving the number of spaces indicated on the spinner. A player may take a shopping card only when he stops on a space so marked. When a player has six different cards he moves, in his turn, toward the parking lot of his color. He must spin the correct number to put him out.

17169.name: Professor Wacky's Wahoo Word Lab
17169.description:
From the Publisher:

Phonics strategies for building words are presented with the fun and engaging Professor Wacky. Players practice making words using onsets (word beginnings) and rimes (word endings). Seven different games accommodate varying skill levels.

17170.name: Frog Pond Fractions Game
17170.description:
From the Publisher:

Croak the frog teaches the beginning concepts of fractions, the relationship of parts to wholes. Game promotes quick play and offers hands-on learning with squeezable, solid foam fraction pieces. Multiple skill levels can play together and game adapts as skills progress.

17171.name: Let's Go Shopping Game
17171.description:
From the Publisher:

Kids learn smart consumerism at the shopping mall as they practice addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. Fun-filled game builds money math skills and involves all players at every turn. Two versions to challenge multiple skill levels.

17172.name: Professor Wacky's Neon Number Flash Game
17172.description:
From the Publisher:

Learn number sense through fun, strategic play. Versatile cards build math skills including reading and writing numbers, multiplication and division, finding prime and composite numbers, and more! Ten different games encourage collaboration and strategizing, and adapt to varying skill levels.

17173.name: Chip-O! Game
17173.description:
From the Publisher:

The fun, challenging game that combines two compatible skills, picture word recognition and rhyming. Players learn 48 different words and how to strategize in a game format. Colorful game board features photos for real-life learning.

17174.name: Take Four Word Game
17174.description:
From the Publisher:

A fast-paced crossword game everyone plays at the same time. Ready, Set, Go!
• Everyone takes four tiles and starts building words.
• First to use their tiles yells, "Take Four" more!
• Players can change and rearrange their crossword anytime
• Use the last tile and WIN!
Easy to learn, it teaches word building, problem solving, creativity and strategic thinking.

17175.name: The Iguana Factor Multiplication Game
17175.description:
From the Publisher:

Leaping Lizards! What a great way to master multiplication tables! Friendly iguanas watch every move as kids use multiplication facts to reach their goal. Bumping and capturing moves make this game even more fun.

17176.name: Buy It Right Shopping Game
17176.description:
From the Publisher:

Teach kids the importance of money recognition, adding and making correct change through interactive game play. Kids can set prices, buy and sell items and learn the value of money as they move throughout the game board.

17177.name: Pharaoh's Phonics
17177.description:
From the Publisher:

Spin your way to building better phonics skills with our Pharaoh’s Phonics game. Multiple skill levels teach long and short vowels, explore beginning blends and practice consonant sounds. Players challenge each other to build 3, 4, 5 and 6-letter words. The student with the first completed pyramid wins.

17178.name: Operation Space Chase
17178.description:
From the Publisher:

It takes mathematical agility to pilot this fleet of space ships! Players use their place value and addition/subtraction skills to try to move all of their ships to the space station first. A great way to make practicing math a "blast".

17179.name: Connexxions
17179.description:
Connexxions is a game where you must move your pieces to capture areas of the board. The game allows you to unsettle other captured areas by supplanting their pieces with your own.
The game encourages you to change to rules to increase difficulty and extend play time.

17181.name: Stad - Land - Rivier
17181.description:
"Ever-changing, fast-thinking town-country-river game using the flower-shaped dice randomizer. Flower shape is rolled between two hands, placed flat on the table; players race to write down words using the right letters."

Every player has to write down what comes to mind with each of the six categories combined with the first letter from the dice randomizer.

Six categories are placed on the board (for example: town, country, river, car, beverage, food, TV-star, singer, etc.) and the dice randomizer is placed. Now everyone has to write down a TV-star, country etc. with the first letter that's attached to it.

Points are given for every right answer, unless someone else has given the same answer.

boardgamecompilation.18272: Play Winning Card Games For Three

17183.description: Traditional three player trick taking card game originating in Eastern Europe. It is quite unusual in that the trump suit can change multiple times per hand due to card play.

boardgamecompilation.159982: Blankety Blank / The Price Is Right: Gameshow Duo

17184.description:
"Blankety Blank" is a board game based on the horrible, yet amazingly long running low budget UK BBC TV quiz show of the same name first introduced by Terry Wogan in 1977 then Les Dawson and Lily Savage (a.k.a Paul O'Grady) respectively later on in its lifespan, the show itself is based on the 1970's version of the US Game Show MATCH GAME.

The game simply involves guessing the missing "blank" in a sentence. The sentence itself often gives an innocuous clue to the blank. Players then compare answers and score points for matching answers.
One player acts as quizmaster and the other players take turns to be a "contestant" and a "panelist." The quizmaster decides who the first contestant is going to be the first question is read out and the contestant and panelists write their answers on the sheet provided.

When everyone has recorded their answer, the contestant reads out his answer first, followed by each panelist in turn. Each time that the answer of the contestant matches that of the panelist the contestant gets a point.

The two contestants with the highest number of points then go on to play the "Super Match Game." In this game there are three possible answers to each question--the answers are worth 50 points, 100 points or 150 points. When a player matches any of these answers, they record the number of points won. The player with the most points at the end of the Super Match is the winner and goes on to the Head to Head game, the last round.
17184.name: Blankety Blank

17185.name: ElementO
17185.description: ElementO was designed as a learning tool for the Periodic Table of Elements. Players acquire elements by landing on them. When another player lands on an element, which is owed, they must pay the owner protons. The last player with protons wins. This game is a scientific variant of Monopoly. If you are into science, teaching or the Periodic Table of Elements this game is for you. The game board depicts the Periodic Table of Elements.

17186.name: Fistful of Power
17186.description:
In a dark age, in a forgotten time, there is a world called Scar. Here, fighters are forced to do battle for the amusement of an evil warlord named Xar. Only a Fistful of Power can destroy him. It's up to you to build an army and throw down the challenge, before all is lost.

This is a ultra-low skill dice-rolling game where the miniatures themselves are rolled. (similar to Pass the Pigs, but much simpler.) Simply throw the figures on the table, and count the point values (printed on the sole of the figures' feet) of the ones that landed face up.

17187.description:
The Barbie Sparkle Kingdom game is very much like a Barbie themed Candyland. Rather than drawing cards with colors on them, the player spins a spinner, chooses a flower on the spinner, looks under the flower for the color and moves their piece to the next space on the board of that color. If that space has a flower, the player gets another turn. If the player lands on a bumble bee, they have to go back to the spot of the previous bumble bee on the board. There are short cuts (Rainbow Bridge, Butterfly Trail, Crystal Path) to speed you along your route. The winner is the player to be the first to Barbie's Jeweled Palace.

Components:
1 glittery game board
4 Barbie playing pieces
1 flower spinner with base
5 plastic flowers
50 glittery stickers
1 spinner and playing piece label sheet
Instructions
17187.name: Barbie Sparkle Kingdom Game

17188.name: The Original Fortune Telling Board Game
17188.description:
From the back of the box:

"The Original Fortune Telling Board Game " by Jennifer Sands is the only board game of its kind that combines a fun and safe methodology based on modern fortune card readings and empowered by real mystical stones. With a roll of the dice each player is whisked away on a journey to discover his or her special personalized fortune. Collect, win, lose or buy LOVE, MONEY, PEOPLE and Question cards in this fun and exciting game where all players win a real personalized fortune card reading of their own.

---

Each player rolls the die, moves his or her pawn, and then does what the landed on square tells them to. This is almost always either gaining or losing fortune telling cards (from four different decks - love, money, people, and questions) or empowering stones (which can be traded in for fortune telling cards). The rules state that the "object is for each player to collect as many fortune telling cards as possible"; but they also state that the winner "is the player who draws the last card," which ends the game and allows that player to discard up to three of their cards.

The real purpose is for each player to use the cards collected during the game to have their personal fortune told on the tarot-style card layout board.

If you believe in this stuff, you'll be happy to know that "all Jennifer Sands products are created with the assistance of professional psychics, fortune tellers and astrologers. All Jennifer Sands products use safe fortune telling methodologies."

If you don't believe in this stuff, you'll note "this product is for entertainment purposes only."

17190.name: MINT 400 Off Road Game
17190.description: During the first phase of the game, the players roll and move on the outer part of the board, getting their trucks, coupons, and spare parts. After using the coupons to pay the "entrance fee", they begin doing a pre-determined amount of laps on the inner part of the board. The more laps that were chosen, the more spare parts that will be needed to complete the laps. There are also "good news" and "bad news" squares on the outer and inner board, which act as random events. The player who completes all the laps, or makes the most number of laps, wins. The rules book also contains more info on off-road racing and contains driver profiles on Parnelli Jones, Team MacPherson (Jerry McDonald, Jeff MacPherson, adn Joe MacPherson), John Baker, Walker Evans, Ivan Stewart, and Kjell Eriksson.

17191.name: Stocks & Shares
17191.description:
The object of the game is to buy and sell shares in four commodities. Players draw cards that dictate the rise and fall in values and buy or sell accordingly. The skill is in observing the actions of others, predicting the trend of the market and maximizing profit.

A simple game with no upper limit to the numbers of players which is unusual. A typically compact Pepys product with a production style similar to contraband; it is a re-implementation of Win-A-Lot, which was also produced by Pepys.

17192.name: PiQadilly Circus
17192.description:
From the publisher:
"PiQadilly Circus, the "Wonderful Wonderland Word Game," is alive with the spirit of Victorian whimsy. PiQadilly is both a thoughtful word game and a wild, spirited board game. This is a game that kids love to play, the perfect meeting place for adults and children. 2 to 4 players make crossword-style wordplays, then "riffle along the ruffle" in a madcap race. Word game and crossword enthusiasts will love it! (New Family Classic Game)"

17193.name: The Wizard of Menlo Park
17193.description:
From the publisher:
"The Wizard of Menlo Park turns you into one of Thomas Edison’s enthusiastic but overworked assistants. Help Edison develop, test, and assemble the incandescent light and the electrical system that would revolutionize the world. Can you help Edison to achieve the seemingly impossible before New Year’s Eve 1879?"

17194.name: The Wright Brothers
17194.description:
From the publisher:
"The Wright Brothers has you travel the path of discovery that led to one of the greatest triumphs of technology — the invention of the airplane. If you’ve gained enough knowledge and experience, be the first to successfully fly the Wright’s airplane, the Flyer, on the sand dunes at Kitty Hawk."

17195.description: For three days in July 1863, 170,000 men, all Americans, fought a climactic battle that would change the course of the American Civil War. Now you and an opponent face off in this action-packed Battle of Gettysburg simulation game. Your units do battle on a high quality mounted map which features various terrain types including streams, roads, woods, towns, railroads and stone walls in this game of "America's bloodiest battle".
17195.name: Gettysburg: Three Days in July

17196.name: Extreme Rock Climbers
17196.description: YOU control your climber up the terrain of this mountain. It's over 2' tall! Special magnetic grippers that you wear on your fingers make contact with your climber's hands. Try to get to smoother paths if you can as flags mark how far you have gone. Position your climber on a hook if you need to plan you next move. But don't wait too long! After three climbs, the player who has climbed the most distance wins!

17197.name: Hoplomachia
17197.description:
From the website (http://perfectcaptain.50megs.com/captain.html):

Miniatures rules for classical Greek warfare!
Covers the period of the Peloponesian War through to
the Theban War. Includes Satrapal Persian armies and
lists for the city states of Greece, and even the Thracians!

Totally new and innovative system geared specifically for the period.

Excellent quality graphics!

This is a web-published game that is free to download and play.

17198.description: Animal Twister differs from regular Twister in that there is no spinner and you use cards representing animals and limbs. The object of this game is to be first to place a hand or foot on the animal called and you win the card, who ever has the most animal cards when the cards run out is the winner. This is from Milton Bradley's "a stockin' feet game" series.
17198.name: Animal Twister

17199.description: The object of the game is to score points by placing tiles so they form continuous lines. Each tile is a square with bars connecting either the opposite sides, the opposite corners, or both. The board is plastic with an 8x8 grid of circular holes, and the tiles have circular bases that fit into the holes. Each turn, a player places one of his tiles on the board and scores for any straight lines formed connecting the bars on the piece just played with the bars on adjacent pieces.
17199.name: Link-Up

17200.description: A children's game of dominoes. The pieces are made of thick cardboard showing two engines on each card. The game can be played as a memory game similar to concentration or a simple matching game. The game helps develop memory, color and shape recognition.
17200.name: Thomas the Tank Engine & Friends Domino Game

17201.description: This is a children's matching game to learn the alphabet. Each left piece is a letter and the right piece is an Engine whose name starts with that letter.
17201.name: Thomas the Tank Engine & Friends ABC Game

17202.description:
This is an expansion for Fantasy Unlimited's Space Race game. It is actually bigger than the original, with 63 pages of optional rules and new scenarios.

The new optional rules include

Delay mission
Production costs
Quality control
Safety
Altitude records
Duration records
Publicity
Advanced mission planning
Rescue mission
Budget cuts & overruns
Insurance
Espionage & counterespionage
New types of satellites

The new scenarios are

Original game with new charts
Space in the 1970s
Combining missions
Campaign game
Historical game (US vs USSR)
Business player (has to make a profit)
Solitaire scenarios
Mini-games (short scenarios)

Expands:

Space Race
17202.name: Space Race Expansion Kit

17203.name: Trekkers: Genocide
17203.description:
This is a "futuristic checkers" style of game, and you even get spaceships based upon very familiar themes, shows, or genres that are very easy to recognize. The acrylic gameboard is 3-sided with triangular areas depicted upon this allowing for a third player to be introduced if so desired. You also get to choose which two kinds of spaceships you'd like for this, from a selection of over a dozen available types.

In the box:
Acrylic gameboard
Rules
2-sets of metal-cast polished pewter spaceships
A cloth storage bag for those pieces

You have to order an additional set of the spaceships if you want to play a 3-Player game.

17204.description:
A partnership trick taking game that consists of two phases:

In the first phase players bid for "Control Cards" that will give them a special action in the second phase. Bidding is done with face up cards that the high bidder then distributes to the other players when he takes the Control Card.

Phase two is a trick taking game in which players may play the Control Cards to a trick to affect its outcome.

Some of the cards have 1 or 2 stars on them. The score for the hand is the number of tricks taken times the number of stars won.

From the box:
You never thought that collecting nuts would be so addictive! Play as a partnership or play head to head as you attempt to be the squirrel in control.

Be careful though in order to gain control you have to give control. Experience the excitement as you exert your control, gather nuts and become top squirrel.

Warning: With enough play you may become a Control Nut too!
17204.name: Control Nut!

17205.name: Bandito
17205.description:
from the publisher website:
Hands up!“ the bank robbers shout as they ride at full gallop into the western town. This quiet little town has never seen so much action as the sheriff gets a posse together to chase after the robbers. Is it the man with the beard or perhaps the one with the red scarf? The player who recognizes the robber in the wanted poster first, receives a deputy badge. He can only be made sheriff if he manages to catch more than one robber. Contents: 24 cards, 1 picture frame, 1 sheriff’s star, 5 deputy stars, instructions

17206.name: Doppia Coppia
17206.description:
Doppia Coppia appears to be a game in a series, TuttiGiochi, published by Dal Negro. The 1987 F. X. Schmid copyright implies it may have been publisehd by that company too. Other games in the TuttiGiochi series (listed in the rules leaflet) are 'Micio-Gatto', 'Gioco Dei Nomi', 'Roulette Scozzese', 'La Torre Di Babele' and 'Sole, Luna E Stelle'.

Doppia Coppia means 'two pairs' in Italian, and reflects the objective of the game - to form a square using two pairs of pieces in two different colours. This simple abstract game for two players consists of a 5-by-5 square board, 5 red pieces and 5 yellow pieces. Pieces of the same colour start in a row at opposite ends of the board and players take turns to move a piece of their colour one square at a time orthogonally. A piece may also jump over one other piece as a move. The central square on the board is occupied by a four-leaf clover and pieces may not enter this square nor jump over it. A player wins when he or she makes a move that completes a square (I interpret this to be a 2-by-2 square) containing 2 red and 2 yellow pieces (the two colours may be side-by-side or crossing diagonally).

17207.name: Catchpenny

boardgameversion.97317: Chatham Hill Games Gray edition w/ Games 100 mark

17207.description:
Use the money of old England to buy, sell and trade with each other. "Buy My Wares?" cards make every sale a different one.

Build the largest mon-o-polies of street pedlars and tradespeople. Beware, you can lose pedlars in many situations and there are many pitfalls for the careless!

Money will come and go, and for those who find themselves with none, arrest and Debtor's Prison are only a step away.

Catchpenny includes a game board, 6 pawns, two dice, 40 Street Pedlar cards, 12 State Lottery tickets, 11 Arrest Warrant cards, 36 Dame Fortune's Tricks cards, 36 Buy My Wares? cards, the Bailiff playing piece and 144 coins representing Crowns, Shillings, Sixpence and Pence, and 8-page Rules booklet.

17208.description:
"This is an entertaining card game of strategy and chance based on WWII naval combat, when fleets combined the awesome firepower of traditional battleships with long-range bombing strikes from aircraft carriers. Players determine when and how to seek combat; to use daylight for smashing carrier air strikes through defending fighters and dense anti-aircraft fire or to use the dark of night for quick and devastating surface attacks using the battleships' big guns. Submarines, destroyers, mines and torpedo boats also all play their roles."

Two to Four players command squadrons of battleships and aircraft carriers and the side that scores the most victory points by sinking enemy vessels and winning sorties wins the game.

Variations in ship attack, capability, and defense values are represented by using different types and numbers of dice.
17208.name: Battlegroup

boardgamehonor.8851: 2007 Golden Geek Best Party Board Game Nominee

17209.description:
Out of the Box calls it "The Game Where Movie Fans Connect!"

"Can you name a film taking place over the holidays AND features a character in a uniform? Then Cineplexity may be the movie game for you!" Players try to be the first to name a movie that meets the criteria on two different Cineplexity cards.

Each of the 315 cards has a description from one of nine categories: Actors, Characters, Critiques, Genre, Production, Props, Scenes, Setting and Theme. Two cards are shown at a time. Who will be the first to think of a movie set In the Future that Contains Foreshadowing? If you come up with a name that players agree satisfies both cards, you win the oldest of the two cards, and a new card is added. So now the challenge might be to find a title that Contains Foreshadowing and has a Dance Sequence. And so on. If everyone is stumped you add a third card, and they must find a title that satisfies two of the three cards. Six to ten points (cards) are needed to win, depending on the number of players.
17209.name: Cineplexity

17210.name: Robot Rampage:  Rise of the Appliance
17210.description:
This is the first non-RPG game from 3am Games, a new company whose first release was in June 2004. "Robot Rampage: Rise of the Appliance," a beer-and-pretzels style card game, is due out in June, 2005.

From the back of the box:

You're tinkers and engineers who have come to the scrap yard to test your mettle. From parts and pieces carefully picked from heaps of junk, construct killer robots capable of visiting devastation and ruin upon all who oppose them. Then, send them into a no-holds-barred, anything goes bot battle to see who's got the roughest robot in the scrap yard! Well, maybe these bots aren't that threatening. But it's still fun to let 'em duke it out!

17211.description:
Monkey Arena is a fast-paced, monkey combat board game from 3am Games. From the back of the box:

Eight monkeys enter, one monkey leaves! The incompetent zoo keeper has left the zoo cages unlocked, leaving the residents to do as they please. The primates have gathered in the monkey cage to see who’s the toughest monkey around. Anything goes in this hair-pulling, rock-throwing, no-holds-barred cage match. Sticks, slaps, rakes, and pokes are the means by which the alpha male will emerge from the melee. Pick a monkey, enter the ring, and let the rumble begin in this wacky game of simian combat.
17211.name: Monkey Arena

17212.name: War of the Daleks
17212.description:
Based on the popular Dr Who baddies "War of the Daleks" is a kind of sci-fi Space-Ludo with Daleks!

The game involves moving card Dr Who figures around a circular playing area aiming to get to the "control center" whilst avoiding the Daleks. The Daleks themselves are faithful plastic renditions about three quarters of an inch tall, inserted into concentric slots cut into the board. When the pale blue "control centre" hub in the middle of the board is rotated, the card disc underpinning these concentric slots also rotate, causing the Daleks to move around the board and "capture" hapless players.

If a player makes it to the central hub, they have a chance to destroy the control centre by lifting it up. Doing so reveals four panels one of which depicts the "King Dalek." If he's next to you he exterminates you and you start again!

17213.name: Vierzig Vagabunden
17213.description:
Each player draws a card to determine their playing colour, which remains secret during the game. The players try to distribute 40 pawns in four colours in such a way that each field on the board (8x5) will be occupied only by one single pawn. The eight rows will be scored at the end of the game. Players reveal the colour and receive victory points for having the most pawns in their colour per row. The player with the most victory points wins the game.

Edition Spielbox No. 57

17214.description: In ‘Conquest for Morundir’ two players fight it out on a hex-tiled game board and steer their pawns (three dukes and six knights) to victory. First player to conquer castle Morundir (the hex field in the middle of the board) with one of their dukes or to eliminate the other player’s three dukes wins the game.
17214.name: Die Eroberung von Morundir

17215.description:
The first animal in space was a dog. True or False? The sun is a star. True or False? Learning about our solar system is much more than memorizing planets! It’s full of fascinating facts. Earn planet cards for correct answers. Put the planets in the right order, and you win!

Blast off into a learning journey through space! Be the first to collect all the planets in the solar system by answering the True/False question cards. Watch out for the black hole, asteroid belt and supernova - you might get lost in space!

* Teaches fascinating facts about our solar system
* Planet Fact Sheet Included
* Includes two challenging levels of game play

Contents:
Planet Quest Board Game - unfolds to 48" across!
4 Astronaut Game Pieces
Spinner
Guide
132 Game Cards
Planet Facts
17215.name: Planet Quest

17216.name: Glück, Verstand und Edelsteine
17216.description: ‘Luck, Wit and Gemstones’ is a tile placement game. The tiles are divided into simple geometric shapes in four different colors, red, green, blue and yellow. Many tiles will also show one or two gemstones. Players place tiles and build complete chamber-like structures in their respective colors and try at the same time to maximize the number of gems that are enclosed in the chambers. Person with the most gemstones in closed, finished chambers of their color wins the game.

17217.name: Titanic Trivia
17217.description: The Titanic Trivia Board game includes 1000 questions tastefully presented in four levels: Novice, Cruiser, Buff and Historian. Players will be asked critical facts about the building of the ship, the ship's decor, the journey, the crew, the tragedy, and the aftermath. Participants from the casual movie viewer to the hard core historian will thoroughly enjoy this exciting game.

17218.name: The Self-Esteem Game
17218.description: Play the game that builds, boosts and bolsters Self-Esteem! You'll start your journey under a cloud in Mopesville and make your way toward feeling good good good about yourself! You'll get brainwashed with positive affirmations and learn to cope with problems along the way. Whether or not you're the first to finish, you'll get a lot of out of playing The Game Where Everybody's a Winner!

17219.name: Onto the Desert
17219.description:
Take a wild trek Onto the Desert. Play this exciting interactive game of survival and become a part of the intricate web of desert life. Beautifully illustrated cards represent plants and animals that are found in the desert. Element cards represent the powerful forces of nature.
Reveal the awesome balance of nature as you follow the chain of life found in the desert.

17220.description:
From back cover :

It is time for your miniature armies to join the navy! Now you can finally add naval, shore, for, and fleet encounters in your 25mm miniature gaming!

Game Features:

Historical Rules! Ships and ordinance are based on historical examples, as well as national differences in crew types. C.1400-1650!
Fantasy Rules! Magic spells, fantasy races, fell beasts, and more!
A plethora of vessels, both sailing and oared, with the option to design your own!
Heavy ordinance, small arms, boarding actions and Ramming - mayhem for everyone!
Custom design rules for star forts, shore batteries, bastions, and buildings!
Expand your games with a complete campaign system that doesn't bog down!
Easy to learn and play! Skill is more important that luck, but luck doesn't hurt!
17220.name: Pirates!  Miniature Battles on the High Seas

17222.name: Marathon Beginner's
17222.description:
From the box:

The MARATHON BEGINNER’S edition is a highly educational question-answer game, prepared under pedagogical supervision specially for children of elementary school age.

MARATHON BEGINNER’S has more than 2500 questions about school and cultural matters, classified in three difficulty levels. 240 cards use vivid graphics of famous people, monuments, animals, and many other familiar object to stimulate your child’s imagination and memory.

Your child will begin a 10 Kilometer “run” against IGG KNORANZ, the mightiest representative of the imaginary country “I-DON’T-KNOW”.

31249.name: World of Warcraft: The Boardgame – BlizzCon Epic Armor Pack

17223.description:
From the Publisher's site:

Take on the role of a chivalrous paladin or a wise shaman, a holy priest or a vile warlock, a mighty mage or a crafty rogue. Play as a savage orc, a mighty tauren, a tribal troll, or one of the Forsaken undead; become an ingenious gnome, a doughty dwarf, a mysterious Night Elf, or a noble human.

Based on the popular World of Warcraft Massively Multiplayer Online Game from Blizzard Entertainment, World of Warcraft: the Board Game invites the players to choose from 16 characters, drawn from the eight races and nine character classes of the Warcraft universe, and take up arms for the glory of the Horde ... or the Alliance. Travel across Lordaeron, vanquish monsters, gain experience and power, and earn honor for your faction.

World of Warcraft: the Board Game is a team-based fantasy adventure. The Horde and the Alliance factions must compete to be the first to defeat the invincible Overlord – be it the lich Kel'Thuzad, the dragon Nefarian, or the demon Kazzak – or, failing that, to be the last faction standing when it comes to all-out war!















Spare parts are available here: https://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/1581438/spares-parts-ho...
17223.name: World of Warcraft: The Boardgame

boardgameimplementation.104162: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)

62329.name: Descent / Runebound / Runewars Figure: Jonas the Kind

boardgamehonor.8854: 2006 Golden Geek Best Gamer's Board Game Nominee

17226.description:
Descent: Journeys in the Dark is a semi-cooperative game in which two to five players will take on the antagonistic roles of heroes and Overlord. Up to four players will choose characters with a wide assortment of skills and innate abilities to be the heroes who will explore dungeons in search of treasure and adventure. One player will take on the role of the Overlord and will control the dungeon's many traps, puzzles, and monsters.

The heroes' goal will be to cooperatively conquer the dungeon, seize its many treasures, and achieve other objectives as set by the scenario. If the heroes cooperate and achieve their goals, they will all win. The Overlord's objective is simply to use all the means at his or her disposal - from deadly traps and ferocious monsters - to kill the heroes. Each hero has a certain Conquest Point value to the party and if too many Conquest Points are lost through hero death, the party loses and the Overlord wins.

Re-implemented by:
