Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition) (2012)
17226.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark

17227.name: Yankee Trader
17227.description:
Players start from San Francisco on an around the world trading trip. By buying and selling wisely at various ports around the world players may make a profitable voyage.

Players start with 10,000 in cash which is used to invest in various goods that are available at different ports along the way.

First player to get to New York gets a bonus payoff for being the fastest finisher.

Whoever makes the most money on the trip wins the game

17228.description:
The game itself is simple. 16 tiles are played from a pool of tiles. The player unable to play a tile loses. There are several rules about playing a tile, but it is basically like dominoes.

The 16 tiles each are laid out with a 3x3 grid which can or can not have a pip in each spot in the grid, but the center spot never has a pip in it. There are none to eight pips along the edges of the tiles.

17229.name: Monopoly: Duel Masters
17229.description:
Join aspiring duelist Shobu and his friends in this special Monopoly edition. All your favorite characters and creatures are included as you move around the board to build up your Duel Masters deck. Collect creatures and spells from all of the five civilizations to become the best duelist in the game!

You can play the standard Monopoly game, buying and selling creatures and properties, or you can add the special gameplay to make this adventure even more exciting.

Contents:
· 6 Collectible Duel Masters Tokens! Shobu, Mimi, Knight, Hakuoh, Kyoshiro, Rekuta
· Gameboard
· 28 Title Deed cards
· 16 Creatures cards
· 16 Spells cards
· 6 Duel Masters character tokens
· 1 pack of Duel Masters Monopoly money
· 32 houses
· 12 hotels
· 2 standard dice
· Instructions

17230.name: Stratego: Duel Masters
17230.description:
Duel Masters Stratego is an advanced version of Stratego set in the famous Anime setting. Unlike most classic game re-themes, Duel Masters Stratego introduces rules changes that allow the game to stand on its own.

From the game's box:

When the forces face off- who will survive?

It's a face off between all of the five forces! When Light, Nature and Water take on the fearless armies of Darkness and Fire- which team will capture the enemy's flag.

Like the Kaijudo Masters themselves, STRATEGO puts you in command of armored vehicles and ruthless creatures. Mark your territory and advance your forces on the gameboard.

17231.name: The Game of Bombardment
17231.description:
The Game of Bombardment recreates naval battle during the Spanish-American War. It is played with either 2 players, or four players in partnership. A spinner is used to determine bombardment values, and play continues until one fleet or the other is sunk.

Contents: spinner, 10 markers in each color, rules printed on game box lid, and a lovely illustration of shore-cannons engaging a naval fleet.

17232.name: Mega Raider
17232.description:
From the promotional blurb:

"Wealth and power beyond your wildest dreams are yours...by building a fortune in companies and cash. Outwit and out bluff other players when you secretly bid to takeover their companies. Top secret information and late-breaking news add to the excitement."

Contents:
board, 2 dice, 6 player tokens, spinner, bid forms, play money, rules, stock cards, and event cards.

17233.name: Turn or Burn
17233.description: Turn or Burn is a print-and-play game of space fighter combat for 2 to 8 players. To start a game, players design their fighters from a deck of system cards. Each turn, players plot a single action by playing a system or maneuver card face down. After everyone has played a card, the actions are revealed. Movement is governed by Newtonian mechanics in 2 dimensions. Combat is resolved by pulling cards from a hand made up of the target fighter’s system cards plus a number of “miss” cards based on range and other factors.

17234.name: Whickers World
17234.description:
A Family game for 2-6 players themed loosely around the TV Series Whickers World.

Components:

Gameboard
250 Question Cards (2000 questions)
Dice
Counters
Rules

Players move round the board through a combination of dice throws and answering questions from the cards.

During his turn a player earns the right to move any of his or her four counters by correctly answering the first question (of 6) on a card - this question normally refers to a picture on the reverse of the card.

The distance moved is determined by dice roll - this roll also being used to determine the number of the next question to be answered (from the same card). If the player answers the question correctly they may roll the dice again and have another question asked (from the same card). Play continues in this manner until a question is answered incorrectly or the same number is rolled twice on that particular card. It is then the next player's turn.

Movement is also influenced by certain of the cards and instructions written on the board.

There is also an element of tactical play in that landing one of your counters on the same square as another player's counter you send that counter back to that player's start point.

The winner is the first player to take all of their four counters around the world (the board) from their start to their finish point.

boardgamehonor.19201: 2005 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Childgame Nominee

17235.description:
Mago Magino editions: The evil Witch has taken all crystals from the Wizard Mago Magino. The children have to help him to collect the crystals. But the witch (in the form of a witch-like spinner) can still transform the children into small frogs. So beware.



Sunshine Rescue: Children rescue pieces of sunshine and the sun rescues the children!


Children skip through the field or take the rainbow shortcut to try and rescue pieces of sunshine. Watch out as the storm cloud spins, if it points at a child they must hide under their umbrella until the sun can rescue them. The first player who brings back three pieces of sunshine wins the game.
17235.name: Mago Magino

17237.description:
Suez to Golan is a very detailed simulation of tactical combat during the October War of 1973. In addition to being published separately, the game was also published as one half of the two game package Mech War 2 (Red Star/White Star II is the other half of the set.)

Key aspects of Suez to Golan include: The issuance of commands to companies, movement in both column and dispersed formations, infantry fatigue and resting, direct fire (by automatic weapons, main guns, and ATGMs), close assault, indirect fire, morale, minefields, aircraft and air defense, ammunition depletion, effects of night, river crossings, engineers, and electronic warfare.

The Arab and Israeli units are mostly platoons. Each hex is 200 meters across and each game-turn represents five minutes.

The game has 800 counters and two mapsheets. One map depicts the Suez Canal and environs, and the other depicts a region in the Golan Heights.

There are thirteen scenarios in Suez to Golan. A comprehensive guide to scenario design is also included.


Components :


Map: 22" x 34" single sheet
Counters: 800 pieces
Rulebook: 1 standard; 1 exclusive


Stats :


Average Playing Time: 3-25 hours
Number of Players: Two-? Player
Complexity: High
Suitability for Solitaire Play: Moderate
17237.name: MechWar 2: Suez to Golan

17238.name: MindRings
17238.description:
The box cover invites you to "Turn your Mind to the Challenge".

A four-in-a-row variant where the board is made of concentric rings that can be rotated. Players place one peg at a time into empty spots and then use that peg to rotate the ring.

The game comes with "standard" and "advanced" rules; the advanced rules allow players to capture pairs of opponent's pegs. In either set of rules, the first to get four of their pegs in a radial row wins.

boardgamehonor.20862: 2005 Origins Awards Historical Miniature Game or Expansion of the Year Winner

17239.description:
WINNER -- 2006 Origins Award for "Historical Miniatures Game of the Year"

Using 25mm miniatures and some dice, Gutshot is a fast-paced, easy-to-learn game that has you slappin’ leather and blowin’ away the bad guys in a matter of minutes. At its core is a simple system for running one-on-one and small-scale combat set in the American Wild West. It is a fun game that is easy to learn and play; it combines realism, pulp fiction, and a little bit of “Hollywood” thrown in for good measure. Gutshot is a game that captures the spirit and mystique of the American Wild West as portrayed in movies, television, pulp novels, and comic books. It’s the American Wild West of youth and fantasy, not a detailed recreation of history. [from the website]
17239.name: Gutshot

boardgamehonor.19195: 2005 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Foreign Game for Beginners

17240.description:
He who laughs last, laughs best. The board of this roll and move game is made of cards with number values from -10 to +8. The last piece to leave each card (each player has several pieces) must take the card. In the end, the player with most points (or least negative points) wins the game. The game has very few rules and lots of luck.

Online Play


BrettspielWelt (real-time)


Expanded by:

Verflixxt nochmal (That's Life! 1st Expansion)
Verflixxt hoch 2 ((That's Life Squared) is the second expansion to That's Life)




Re-implemented by: Verflixxt! kompakt
17240.name: That's Life!

17241.name: Babble
17241.description:
A fast paced, Bible based, outrageously fun game! Babble!™ is an exciting new Bible game with a fresh style of play. Every player draws two cards and start calling out the words on the cards. Wait, did someone else just yell out "cross"? Yes! A match! Both players place their matching cards together. One player grabs a die and rolls it while the other player calls out "odd" or "even". If the guessing player guesses right, that player gets the match! If not, the player rolling the die gets the match. Each match is worth one point. The players then draw a new card and start calling out words again. Its so simple!
The game contains six decks of cards with each deck being a different category. The six Categories are Symbols, Books, Places, People, Animals, and Things found in the Bible. Each card has five words related to that category. After playing through all six decks the player with the most points wins the game!
Babble!™ is a terrific game for a large number of players. It is great to play with friends, family, and church groups!

17242.description:
This is a game of small unit actions set in the near future. Designed for quickly and simply introducing new players to table top miniature battles. D6 based with simple armor and weapons charts and straight forward combat resolution. The game was designed around Lance & Laser's miniature range of the same name.

http://www.teamfrog.com/fig-sc.htm
17242.name: Star Corps: Call to Battle

17243.description:
A fast playing 25mm table top fantasy battle system. Though any number can play it's best to keep the combatants to no more than four players. An alternate movement system generates unique tactical situations during the course of a turn and allows intelligent strategists to act and react according to plans they set in motion.

Players select a race to field and the appropriate miniatures and design each scenario on a points-based army build system. D20's are used to resolve all combat and other effects. The game comes with photo copyable templates, rosters and counters.
17243.name: Leviathan

17245.name: Pepper
17245.description:
Pepper: a whole new ball game! This "innovative new card game that sends the action in all directions! Throw a ball to anyone’s territory and see if they have what it takes to respond. Find players that can’t handle your throws and win!"

Part of Out of the Box's "Fun to Go" series, the 52 card Pepper game consists a small tin of ten cards of five colors: blue, green, orange, purple, and yellow. Each color set contains two cards of each number: 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. Blue and yellow also have one card numbered 6.

Each player is dealt 5 cards and the rest of the cards are not used in the game. The cards represent balls being thrown from player to player, with the card's number showing its speed. The dealer places one face-up card in front of another player. That player then places one of their cards in front of another player. They may choose a higher-numbered card or a card of the same color from their hand. Alternatively, they may pick up all the cards in front of them, add them to their hand, then choose to play any of the cards in their hand. The winner is the first player to play the last card from their hand to a player who is unable to play.

17246.name: Pantheon

boardgameversion.177531: Out of the Box English Edition

17246.description:
from site:

"The greatest builders of ancient Rome are competing for the favor of the Emperor. Score points by building the biggest, tallest and widest buildings before the building stops. Cleverly out-build the others and all of Rome will be at your feet!"

17247.name: You Be the Judge
17247.description:
You Be The Judge - The game of Real Life Court Dramas.

You be the Judge contains brief descriptions of 500 court cases from around the world.

Players divide themselves into two teams and take it in turns to decide on the outcome of a court case.

One person from Team A selects a card from the box and reads it out loud to Team B, who then have the opportunity to consult with each other before announcing whether they, the jury, are FOR or AGAINST. If they answer correctly then they advance 0, 1, 2, 3 places round the scoreboard, dependant on the number thrown on a dice. If they answer incorrectly, their turn ends immediately.

Team B now reads a case to Team A, who in turn, deliberate and announce their findings . And so on...

The game ends after one Team has completed a circuit of the board (16 spaces).

17248.name: 18GM: The 18XX GameMaster
17248.description:
18GM is an 18xx game development kit. It features a modular board that allows virtually endless scenarios to be developed. The game as printed includes one basic scenario, the Aurora Limited, and several variations on it.

Some of the interesting ideas in 18GM are:

1. Tycoons. These are like private companies in standard 18xx, but allow various special abilities in the stock round, such as exceeding certificate limits or exchanging for shares in the bank pool or initial offering.

2. Buying on Margin: buying a share by paying half now, and half during the next stock round.

3. Making a Market: the president may reduce the price of the Initial Offering shares if the company remains unfloated.

17249.name: Auburnopoly

647.name: Late for the Sky Production Company

17249.description: This is the Auburn University themed version of Monopoly. Unique properties include Toomer's Corner, Jordan Hare Stadium, and Samford Hall. Houses and Hotels are replaced by Credit Hours and Diplomas.

17250.name: Monopoly: London
17250.description: This is a Monopoly game using locals in London, England. The game uses pounds (£) instead of dollars ($). The board is identical, only the names have changed. The Chance and Community Chest cards are brighter and more colorful than a standard Monopoly set. Also the box has a nice insert designed to hold both the money (the bank) and the unpurchased properties.

17251.description:
Arne Junior is the simplified version of Arne classic. The game is playable from the age of 5 and takes about 10-25 minutes to play. artwork on the cards is based on aquarelle hand painting.

pick a fruit. The one to collect most fruits of his color wins. but...you really can do everything to prevent the other players of obtaining exactly this.
You can steal cards, change places, pass on your hand to the next player and play before it is your turn. Also there are big hungry birds flying around on the look out for fruit!

Arne is available in a designer metal tin with instructions in English, German, French and Dutch.
17251.name: Arne Junior

17252.name: Primary Money Chase
17252.description:
From the Publisher:

Young children learn to make change up to a dollar and recognize combinations of pennies, nickels dimes and quarters. For example: 3 nickels and 1 dime equal 1 quarter. The game is fun and competitive as players try to get around the board to their goal at the center of the board.

17253.name: Holey Cow!
17253.description:
From the Publisher:

The UDDERLY INCREDIBULL CARD GAME! Pass and stack your cow cards, count the holes in the Holey Cows and guess whether you have the most or the fewest holes. To win, count up your points and be the first cow to cross the pasture.
Features the pictures of the world renowned CowParade cows!

17254.name: Scooby-doo! Coolsville 500
17254.description:
From the Publisher:

"Start your engines!" It's time for the Coolsville 500-the coolest, fastest race in town. Earn MPH cards that help speed you around the track, but be careful: the Monsters are in the pits! The first player to complete 5 laps wins.

17255.name: Scooby-doo! Where Are You?
17255.description:
From the Publisher:

If you can count to ten you can count on Scooby-Doo to show up when least expected! Play your cards to add, subtract, multiply and divide. Be the first to use all of your cards, you win!

17256.name: Math Around The Home
17256.description:
From the Publishers:

Introduce problem solving challenges that occur in everyday life around the home. Math drill includes basic addition and subtraction of time, temperature, money, metrics, and liquid measurement. For example: Large eggs weigh about two ounces. How many ounces will one dozen eggs weigh?

17257.name: Travel Math
17257.description:
From the Publisher:

Players will have fun with this problem solving activity as they encounter real-life situations that happen on trips. For example: calculating miles per gallon, hours on the road, and costs incurred during a trip.

17258.name: Primary Place Value Chase
17258.description:
From the Publisher:

Here's a great, competitive, fun-filled game. Each player chooses a colored pawn and follows the track around the board by spinning and moving to a specific number in either the ones, tens, or hundreds place. The winner is decided by the first player who makes it once around the board and follows their colored alley to the center of the board.

17259.name: Bank Account
17259.description:
From the Publisher:

Can you balance your checking account? Players learn a variety of processes involved in having a checking account. As they play around the gameboard, they write checks, make deposits, and keep accurate records. Real-life transactions include buying groceries, paying taxes, making car payments and paying medical bills. Checks, deposit slips, and currency from $1 to $100 are included.

17260.name: Allowance
17260.description:
From the Publisher:

Allowance provides a great way to teach young people about earning and saving money, as well as wisely making special purchases. Game cards indicate a task like mowing lawns and cleaning the garage. Choices are made, as in real life, whether to spend money on ice cream, or put it into savings. Coin chips from one cent to fifty cents and currency from $1 to $5 are included.

17261.name: Math and The Beanstalk
17261.description:
From the Publisher:

Here is a unique activity that incorporates basic math drill, using addition and subtraction facts with the growth and development of a bean! Players solve problems correctly and use markers to cover various plant parts including the root, seed, shoot, stem, leaves, and flower. Using addition facts through 9+9 and subtraction facts through 10-10 players become familiar with parts of plants while mastering addition and subtraction facts. The player who covers all sections of his or her plant wins!

17262.name: Road Block
17262.description:
From the Publisher:

Here's a great game that introduces map reading skills and following directions. Players mover around the gameboard and answer questions and set up "road blocks" to stop their opponents. Play money is included and when you reach your destination you receive $5. The first player to accumulate $30 wins!

17263.name: Fattoria
17263.description:
From the Kidult website:

Gasp! What’s up? A group of pretty animals have lost their colours, will you help them come back out? And why don’t you invite your friends and play all together to see who is the fast colourer of the world?

Each kid chooses an animal to colour up and lays it on the table in front of himself. At his turn each kid throws a dice and colours up that part of the animal which is marked by the number on the dice. If that number corresponds to a coloured portion he waits for his next turn and it’s up to the child next. The winner is the one who colours up all of his animal first.

17264.name: FotoCaccia
17264.description:
From the Kidult website:

Fotocaccia is a visual memory game. In a few seconds you have to memorize the opponents’ pets and here starts the Fotocaccia. Enrich your treasure as much as you can.
The winner is the one who manages to click more animals (that is to catch them with photo clicks). An easy and quick game for Kidults and kids. But be careful, children are terrific at this game!

17265.name: KokkoKid
17265.description:
From the Kidult website:

KokkoKid is a very easy game with some surprises in store!

4 hungry fearsome crocodiles go about in a lagoon that separates the stormy river from the lake of tranquility.

The hunting has began, but our crocodiles are not very smart...that's right, they are only able to go straight and imagine this, they do not know how to stop... to do this they must go to the opposite side. Now it is your turn. Will you be able to help your little fish arrive to their destination safely with your die, some cunningness and a touch of luck? The player that will save the most fishes wins.

17266.description:
From the Kidult website:

Who knows which colour dinosaurs were? Nobody! So have fun and colour them as you wish! Dear children, dear parents, who is writing these words has designed the animals you see, he is the father of three wonderful daughters Alessia, Alice and Michela who, like all the other children, are always searching for something new to do and to learn from. These unpublished images and these games are inspired at Bookgames a series of books designed to help parents grow with their children in a more simple way, more profitable and fun: PLAYING WITH THEM.

These games aim at those children that, in most cases, can not read yet or they are learning. That is why every character on a coloured pedestal has a big initial and a name completely written with capital letters. Children love to play: that is why every picture to be cut can become a playing card, or it can be folded along the base so that it stands and be played with.

The Kromosauri game includes 54 pictures to cut, one coloured series of (27), one black and white series of (27) (that you can colour yourself) and a series of (27) presentation cards with a brief story where the character presents himself. There are also the rules to 6 different games to able you to use the picture cards you have cut.

Thanks to this material you could have fun with your children getting them involved (and getting yourself involved) by playing with one of the 6 games offered (or you could make up new ones)
17266.name: KromoSauri

17267.name: Laserburn
17267.description:
Laserburn is a set of science fiction skirmish rules, with roughly 12 to 20 figures a side. It originated as rules for simulating firefights in science fiction role playing games, but soon grew into a set of stand-alone skirmish rules.

Laserburn uses 15mm scale, the basic rulebook is 40 pages in length. Weapons covered are Lasers, bolters, slug gunes, grenade and missile launchers and conversion beams. Armour include flak, mesh, light, power and dreadnought armor.

A number of supplements and scenarios were published for Laserburn as well.

17269.name: The Battle of the Alma
17269.description: 1854. Three scenarios for the French (and Turkish) attack, the British attack, and the Alma Campaign. Two 34" x 22" maps. 300 double-sided die-cut counters. 75 yards per hex, 100 men per strength point. "The chief focus of the game is leadership, with each leader having a Command Rating, a Command Span, and a Combat Bonus Rating." Morale, facing, and formation built into the counters.

17270.name: F*ck This! (Imperialist Warmongers)
17270.description:
from the publisher: "A 29-card expansion set for F*ck This! A set of cards that jump on Osama and his ilk, with a few slaps at the media and politicians while we're at it."

Expansion #3 of F*ck This!.

17271.name: F*ck This! (Keeping It Clean)
17271.description:
From the publisher: "A 29-card expansion for F*ck This! A set of cards that you can use to substitute into the main game for use with those who have more delicate sensibilities than you. Only 29 cards might not be enough to pull it off, but it's a start."

Expansion #4 of F*ck This!.

17272.description:
55 is a stand alone game, and also a 55 dice expansion for "Spiel". There are enough dice included to build a smaller version of the traditional pyramid from Das Spiel. Additional colors and game rules are included to expand the selection of games for Das Spiel. In fact Reinhold Wittig is not the only designer of this collection - there are many games designed by various authors.

Expands:

Das Spiel

17273.name: Championship Basketball
17273.description:
From the Publisher:

Two teams or players use basic addition facts to play this basketball simulation game. Using basketball terms such as "steal the ball" and "shoot from the key" , 18 different plays make this a great game for sports enthusiasts of all ages.

boardgamehonor.8858: 2006 Golden Geek Best Kids' Board Game Nominee

17274.description:
One of the most innovative additions to the boys action aisle is ATTACKTIX. Launching with Star Wars: Episode III toys, ATTACKTIX is a battle figure game that combines great action figures with kinetic battling features.

Each figure comes on a base that contains all of the information that a trading card might include, such as speed, defense, point value and special powers unique to that character.

The goal of the game is simple: be the last one standing; but beyond that there are nearly unlimited strategies. To begin, kids select how many points each squad should start out with, pick their squads and put them into formation. On each turn, kids will move their figures across the table (counting distance using a patented clicking wheel in the base), and then attack with features like slashing light sabers, firing projectiles and others. When the figures are knocked over, their special powers come into play and influence the game. For example, granting another one of your figures an attack or bringing back a figure who may have been previously defeated.

This version is based on characters in the Star Wars Universe.

There are multiple themes in the Attacktix series of games.
17274.name: Attacktix Battle Figure Game: Star Wars

17275.name: Space Insurrection
17275.description:
A game of interstellar conquest available free at http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/Insur.html.

The map consists simply of ten worlds/planets/star systems. Each player begins with one loyal world with a Governor and a hand of 7 chits drawn from the pool. The pool consists of 10 of each type of unit (except for two of the installations, of which there are only 5 each) and 2 each of several (optional) special chits that allow the holder to execute special actions.

There are four different types of units: Personalities(in two types: Public and Espionage), Military Units and Military Installations. There are 4 kinds of Espionage personalities, from Assassins to Rebel Leaders, and 3 kinds each of Public Personalities, Military Units and Military Installations.

Each unit has a set of possible actions to choose from. A Governor's actions, for example, are: Recruit-5; Deploy (Personality, Troops)-5; Subdue Uprising-3; while an Assassin has only one available action: Kill (Public Personality)-3. The number following each action indicates the chances out of six that the attempted action will be successful. Recruit allows you to draw a chit from the pool into your hand, while Deploy allows you to place a unit from your hand into play. Loyal worlds have a list of actions just as units do: Recruit-5; Deploy Base-4; Deploy Personality-4; Repair-2.

During the movement phase, a unit may move from its current world to any other world on the map. Military installations may not move. Troops cannot move on their own, but must be transported by Star Cruisers. Star Cruisers may be ordered to blockade a world; any enemy personality moving to a blockaded world risks being destroyed by the blockading cruiser.

Victory is achieved by gaining the loyalty of all ten worlds or by eliminating all enemy units from the map.

17276.name: Nonsense
17276.description: Players compete to be the first to reach 100 "pumpkins" by doing the most unusual tasks: saying a word to other players with a mouth full with water, drawing with a soft pencil, and so on. Fun for grownup children Ages 14 and up

boardgamehonor.20854: 2005 Origins Awards Game of the Year Winner

17277.description:
From the publisher's website:

This 144 page full-color expansion advances the Warmachine storyline and adds new warjacks and warcasters.

Warmachine: Apotheosis introduces new rules that improve the depth of play and enrich the gaming experience for new and veteran players alike. In addition to new warcasters, some old favorites return with new abilities and updated models to reflect advancement and changes to their characters. The book also includes a new map-based campaign system providing story-driven play.

Expands:

Warmachine
17277.name: Warmachine: Apotheosis

17278.description:
From the publisher's website:

Escalation is a 240 page supplement to Warmachine, including stats and rules for dozens of new additions to Warmachine armies, storyline fiction, a campaign, and a full color feature from the renowned 3D department of Privateer Press.

Expands:

Warmachine
17278.name: Warmachine: Escalation

17281.name: Fragrances
17281.description: FRAGRANCES, The Perfect Blend of Art, Perfume and Game, put out by SentoSphere, Paris, France, in 1990. Description: An amusing original family game about perfume. 2-6 players. Age 12 and up. Contents: 24 scent bottles of essences, 5 women's perfume, 3 men's perfume, one mounted playing board, 8 perfume cards, 6 tokens, 1 die, 54 chips, 30 counters, 33 playing cards, rules. This game teaches you about perfume and its various classifications. The essences used in the game were selected from numerous essence producers to give you an idea of the wide range of materials used in the perfume industry.

17283.name: Poker's Wild
17283.description: Score the most points by creating the best poker hand possible using up to any 5 consecutive cards (your card and up to 4 cards adjacent to it- either vertically or horizontally) on the game board on each turn.

17284.name: Kazink
17284.description:
Similar to Sequence. You play a card from your hand and places a chip on the board. But chips doesn't "lock" the board. You can stack chips on top of each other. Stack up three of your chips and it's a crown. Two rows of 3 crowns is needed to win. Use your strategy to stop opponents and crown your chips first!
Is played by 2 or 3 single players or 4 players divided in two teams.

17285.description:
From the publisher:
Chef Alfredo is caught in the middle of a food fight! Children grab their forks and fling their meatballs at the chef as he spins round and round. The first player to stick all of their meatballs on the chef wins. Have some food flinging fun... with no mess to cleanup! Game includes 12 meatballs, 4 flinging forks an 1 spinning chef.
17285.name: Food Fight

17286.name: Calamityville
17286.description:
The game is set under the gold rush boom and bust. Players build up the town during the boom and the town goes broke under the bust.
Much of the action is centered on the donkey in the middle of the board. When a player draws a "Donkey Goes Wild!" card, it bucks its legs to knock down players' buildings. The player with the most assets when the "Gold Runs Out" card is drawn wins.

Game includes 4 characters, 13 buildings, 1 bucking donkey, property deeds, newspaper cards, money, gold nuggets, 2 dice, game board and instructions.

17287.name: Catch That Kiwi
17287.description:
From Box: Kuru, the rare giant KIWI is hungry again. He decides to visit his four favorite shops. But the Kiwi Catchers have other ideas and set out to catch the big Kiwi before he returns to the safety of his rain forest home. Watch Out Kiwi - don't get caught.
Object of the game: The winner is the player who finally catches The Kiwi OR the Kiwi who has visited all four shops and returns safely to the forest.

17288.description:
From the Rules:

"The game of Exploration is a realistic model of the daily events and excitement in an Oil & Gas Exploration Department
Players will instantly find themselves making decisions regarding where to drill, where to run seismic surveys, and how much to bid for prospective land parcels."

Game components include the Drilling Tool (a plastic oil rig with a long pin), the Seismic Tool (a plastic box with iron filings), money, player's score sheets, 4 different-colored Land Owner markers, colored pins to mark drilled wells (White= Dry, Yellow= Average, Red= Super Producers, Black= Wildcat), Crown Land Sale markers, Hazard cards, Windfall cards, and a gameboard with movable multi-stepped, multi-sized Oil Reservoirs placed inside (with magnets embedded in some of the 'super' producing regions).
17288.name: Exploration: The Seismic Game of Oil and Gas

17289.name: Stellar Journey
17289.description:
"Far beyond the Milky Way, undisturbed for billions of years, lies a vast, cold cloud of molecular hydrogen, helium, and dust. Penetrating shock waves from a distant supernova or a close encounter with a passing star disrupts the cloud, setting its gases and dust in motion. Forcibly separated into numerous fragments, the gigantic cloud is transformed into an immense stellar nursery from which hundreds of bright, shining stars will emerge.

To play STELLAR JOURNEY: The Game, each player gathers "mass" to form three stars, plus "time" for each to evolve through all stages from beginning to end. The first player to complete the life cycles of all three - ending in a white dwarf, a neutron star, and a black hole - wins! Whether new to astronomy or a veteran stargazer, whether competing with family, friends, or classmates, whether young or old, STELLAR JOURNEY: The Game is certain to provide hours of wholesome fun, learning, and adventure!

STELLAR JOURNEY: The Game
Simulates star birth from nursery to end stages
Four levels of difficulty permitting players to compete at their own level
No regressive plays - lose your next turn, etc.
GAME CONTENTS:
Game board; game pieces; sixty colorful cards presenting a total of 300 questions at four levels of difficulty; and a booklet containing the rules of play, record charts, game objectives, match to the National Science Education Standards, image credits, and glossary."

Stellar Journey: The game was developed in cooperation with NASA'S Chandra X-ray Center and the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, and The Wright Center for Innovative Science Education, Tufts University.

17290.name: People & Places in The Book
17290.description:
A Bible trivia game a bit different from the usual Trivial Pursuit style.

There are six questions to each answer, in decreasing difficulty (6 being the most difficult). In this game, players progress along a game track. Movement forward (or backward for incorrect answers) is determined by the level of difficulty you are attempting.

There are several types of square, which determine who may answer the question. A solo square means only the person whose marker is on the square may answer. A Free-For-All square means all players have the opportunity to answer. A Proxy square means the active player chooses another player to answer for them; the active player advances on the correct answer, but the proxy goes back if they answer incorrectly. A Blitz square allows everyone to answer as the active player reads the clues from most difficult to easiest. As soon as someone answers correctly, they and the active player move ahead the number of squares matching the level of clue that was the question was answered on.

Each players turn finishes after one move.

There are also Providence cards, which usually result in either going forward or back a number of squares.

First to reach the finish square wins.

17291.name: Can't Cook, Won't Cook
17291.description:
Based on the BBC Television Series of the same name, Can't Cook, Won't Cook is a lighthearted family game for 2 to 6 players Ages 10 and up

From the box:

"They say "If you can't stand the heat then get out of the kitchen!" the same is true of this exciting, fast paced family action packed board game.
It's a race to get your ingredients for a perfect meal traveling up and down the board a few times to collect them. sounds simple...well it would hardly be based on the hit TV show, if it were that easy!!
Firstly, it's against the clock, then it's against another player, then you have to answer some "Can't Cook" or "Won't Cook" questions, oh and did we mention you could be rolling the pastry, tossing the pancake, chopping the herbs, stirring the pans...."

The objective is to move around the board in order to collect points. Points are collected as you collect ingredient tokens. The game ends when the first player has collected all 5 ingredients. Movement is determined by dice roll with each player taking turns to have one minute (a sand timer is provided) to move and accomplish as much as they can.

The spaces on the board dictate the activities to be undertaken on them. These include:
- collecting an ingredient,
- pausing for a cup of tea (rolling until you get a 2),
- answering questions (cookery related - involving choosing your answer from a choice of four) or
- performing an action - stir the pan, roll the pastry, chop the herbs or toss the pancake (the equipment for which is all included with the game)

17292.name: Limbo
17292.description:
Limbo - How Low Can You Go?

Components:
5 Limbo Blocks (wooden blocks (5cm x 5cm x 13cm)
1 Limbo Bar (wooden block (0.5cm x 5cm x 13cm) with Velcro pad
1 Limbo-low-nose (with Velcro pad)

The five limbo blocks are stacked on top of each other on the floor with the limbo bar on the top. Players take it in turns to wear the "Limbo-low-nose" and bend over an pick up the limbo bar with their nose. This must be achieved with only the feet in contact with the floor. Each player has three attempts - players who cannot do this, or touch the floor with any part of their body other than their feet are eliminated.

Once everyone has succeeded or been eliminated the bar is lowered by removing one of the limbo blocks so that the limbo bar is now resting on four blocks. Players now attempt at this height.

Play continues in this way, gradually reducing the height of the bar until either only one player is left or until at least two players have successfully picked up the bar from the floor. If this happens all five blocks are placed under the limbo bar again, and the exercise repeated, but this time players are only allowed to stand on one foot!

17293.name: Delta Force
17293.description:
DELTA FORCE - "The Game of Strategy, Confrontation and Capture. Outwit your opponent in a cunning campaign of sacrifice and counter-sacrifice."

Each player has fourteen triangular pieces numbered from 1 to 14. These are arranged in a matrix on each player's side of board.

Once placed the counters are moved forward towards the center of the board where counters from both sides come "face to face" in the "attack" position. The highest number wins each confrontation.

The winner is the player to capture the most Delta Force counters.

17294.name: Prehistoric Settlements
17294.description:
From the website:

"Set about 50,000 years B.C. in an age of hunter gathers, and the last of the strange large mammals, such as Woolly Mammoths, Sabre-tooth Tigers and Giant Birds, the game is a mixture of board games and wargames and was a daunting task to create. It was easy all we had to do was make it simple and quick to play, whilst still blending in a level of complexity that would keep the players interest alive. Well, I am sure that we have succeeded in doing just that. Using a mixture of Metal Miniatures, Resin Buildings and Cards and Counters, there is very little note taking and working out involved as the counters and cards remove this aspect, and the player is free to work on the most important aspect of the game strategy, and this is what the game is really about!

At the beginning of the game all the players start with the same amount of pieces and the basic idea of the game is to grow your settlement faster than the other players, buying Figures and Buildings with game tokens as you go along, hopefully avoiding Natural Disasters and other unforeseen incidents.The game can be played by 2 or 4 players and is for Ages 14 and up and is fun for families as well as boardgamers & wargamers.

A great deal of time and effort was put into the design of the game pieces, which are very detailed. The same figures are used for each different tribe, which are just painted differently. Spears & Shields are cast separately, but come with the figures that they are intended for. The rules are well printed complete with a color cover, and are packed with black & white illustrations. The game tokens are printed in color, on white card.

To sum up, this was daunting but great fum to create, and to play-test, of which there were many games. There isn't a game like it on the market that I know of, and I know that those who buy a set are going to find it an appealing and tactical game. The more you play the game the faster it becomes and the more you will find that you have learned since the last time you played it."

Currently there are 2 expansions that add Shamans and water taskings:

- "The Savage Seas"
- "Out of the Wilderness"

Check more info at the homepage:
http://www.sbarber-models.clara.net/html/settlement.html

or the yahoo group: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/steve_barber_models/

17295.name: Operation Husky
17295.description:
"It's June 11, 1943 and the Allies are ashore on Sicily...the race to Messina has begun. As the Allied player, you have 12 division of Americans, Canadians and British. In all, 467,000 troops commanded by two of the Allies's best....Your objectives are to sweep the Axis off the island."

The game was published in Combat! #9.

17296.name: Dino-Czars
17296.description:
Back in the days when the great plains were ruled by dinosaurs, the local Tyrannosaurus came to you and your dinosaur friends with a proposition you couldn't refuse: help eliminate the neighboring Tyrannosaurus to open up a new food supply, and you and your friends won't get eaten. Your brain is the size of a walnut, so this 'not getting eaten' bit sounded like a pretty good idea. Little did you realize that the neighboring Tyrannosaurus had the same idea. Who will be the next Dino-Czar?

Dino-Czars is a shogi-like game where the object is to capture the opposing Tyrannosaurus. Up to two captured pieces can re-spawn by hatching eggs, but gestation takes time and causes a player to lose tempo. A computer version is available for the Zillions of Games engine.

17297.description:
The Little Polar Bear Memory is based on the traditional game of memory and can be played that way, with players turning over cards, two at a time, trying to find as many matched pairs as possible through luck or by remembering the location of the cards.
The game has 30 regular picture pairs and 12 special Little Polar Bear cards. This addition makes five variations of the traditional game possible. Some of these are easier to play; some are more challenging and difficult.
17297.name: Little Polar Bear Memory Game

17298.description:
Branches and Twigs and Thorns (or "Barsoomite Go") is an elegant little strategy game for two or four players that uses Icehouse pieces and a chessboard, and a collection of tokens (at least ten per player).

It is a turn-based game, unlike Icehouse or IceTowers; and there is no luck involved. Like Martian Go, Players seek to build chains of pieces of their own color and to force their opponents to branch of from opposing pieces of their opponent's colors, which results in a penalty determined by the sizes of the pieces involved.

Online Play


Super Duper Games
17298.name: Branches and Twigs and Thorns

17299.name: The Great Gumball Game
17299.description:
From the box:

"Pop the Gumball, Match the Color, Win the Game!

Take your own miniature machine, press down the dome, and watch the colored gumball rise to the top! Match the color of the gumball to the next matching-colored space on the board. You’re on your way!"

17300.name: The Masters of the Universe Role Playing Game
17300.description: Skeletor and his evil minions have stolen the Crown Jewels, secreting them away in Snake Mountain. Now He-Man and his companions have entered Skeletor's hideaway deep beneath Snake Mountain to retrieve the lost treasure. In this exciting and fast-paced game, players become the forces of good. As they explore the depths of Skeletor's hideout, searching for the treasure, they will encounter monsters and evil characters, which will try to stop them. Only their cunning will help unless they can find the magic gemstones that will defeat Skeletor's evil.

17301.description:
This is a Japanse wargame on the battles of Nobunaga, part of Sengoku Gunyu-den" series games designed by Makoto Fukuda.

Basic Designer: Makoto Fukuda
System Designer: Hideaki Uehara
17301.name: Nobunaga Fuun-roku

17302.name: Champion of the East
17302.description: This is a Japanese DTP wargame on warfare in medieval Japan, the map can be linked to Hero of the West.

17303.name: Hero of the West
17303.description: This is a Japanese DTP game on warfare in Medieval Japan. Can be linked to the game Champion of the East.

17304.description: This is a Japanese DTP wargame on warfare in ancient China.
17304.name: Chu Han War BC 206-203

17305.name: Mobile Suit Gundam ZZ: Dakar
17305.description: This is a Japanese wargame set on the anime world of Gundam ZZ.

17306.description:
This is 5th game of the 'Sengoku Gunyuden' series.
Republished in Game Journal #62 in 2017.
NB: A "gunki" is a war story (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gunki_monogatari).

This game features Hideyoshi Toyotomi in his path to power.
Hideyoshi is Japan's second "great unifier" after Nobunaga and before Tokugawa.

Three scenarios are included in this game. "Mt. Tennō" represents the battle of Yamazaki, Hideyoshi against Akechi Mitsuhide the betrayer. "Shizugatake" is the battle of the same name, Hideyoshi against Shibata Katsuie the most powerful general in Oda clan. "Masters' Championship" simulates the battle of Komaki and Nagakute, Hideyoshi against Tokugawa Ieyasu the futur shogun. The length of the scenarios is 8 to 12 turns. There are many units but each scenario is playable.

Each player controls one or more clans. The clan's combat units are organized in troops.
There are four action phases in each game turn. The number of phases during which each troop can act is decided by commander's activation ability. In the action phase, each troop selects one action among movement, field combat, siege, moral recovery, reorganization and replacement.

The winner is the player who earns the most victory points. The victory point are awarded by capturing castles and destroying enemy units.

SCALE: each hex of map is roughly 6000 meters. Each game turn represents one week of real time. Each combat units represents about 1000 soldiers.
17306.name: Hideyoshi Gunki

17307.description:
This is the first game of Bandai if Series.

It is rumored that this is the best selling "wargame" in Japan ever!
In fact, this is a family game with wargame design technique.
You have ZOC with battleship counter and retreat into EZOC means ELIMINATION!
Combat is resolved by playing cards.
17307.name: Combined Fleet

17308.name: Yukimura Gaiden
17308.description:
This is a tactical game on the Osaka Castle final siege, summer campaign (1615).

The title is taken from the Japanese popular culture hero "Yukimura Sanada" who was a commanding samurai at the siege of Osaka. A "gaiden" is a tale.

Game Journal edition contents:

2 countersheets
1 map




(Notes: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_Osaka
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanada_Yukimura
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaiden)

17309.name: Height 203
17309.description:
This game is on the climatic battle (or massacre) for Port Arthur during Russo-Japanese War.
Here Japanese lost horrendous casualties by the combination of fearsome firepower and solid entrenchment of Russians.
This battle became the prophesy of the trench warfare of WW1.

17310.name: Midgard
17310.description: Japanese Fantasy wargame on the final battle between the Norse gods.

17311.name: The Siege of Osaka, Summer campaign
17311.description:
Tactical game on the final siege of Castle Osaka.
Title is taken from one of Japanese folk hero "Yukimura Sanada".
He led the small special selected warriors into the horde of Tokugawa army and tried to kill the Tokugawa Ieyasu himself!

Published by Bandai.

17312.name: Saga
17312.description:
From the box:

"Stimulating and absorbing, SAGA is an exciting chase through our Island's wonderful story and its fascinating legends".

The "islands" in this case being the British Isles.

The game comprises:

A board consisting of an outer circle and an inner spiral.
6 Playing Pieces
Pack of 36 SAGA cards (6 sets of 6 cards - each showing the date and details of a significant event in British history)
Pack of 16 BLACK SPOT cards (also showing other events in British history)
Dice
SAGA Bonds (money)

Traveling around the outside circle of the board each player has to try and collect five SAGA cards, each of a different color. As each card is collected the player claims its cash value from the Exchequer (Bank).

When the cash and five cards have been amassed, the player then moves to the center spiral and races towards the finish. Each time a player lands on a Black Spot he must pay the penalty as shown on a BLACK SPOT card.

The winner is the first player to reach the finish without going bankrupt. Bankrupt players still have a chance to win - by going back to the start and beginning the journey through history again.

17313.name: Auf Zack!!

boardgameversion.259919: Drei Hasen in der Abendsonne edition

17313.description:
The game has 44 picture tiles in pairs, showing items like snails, nails, stars, churches and so on. Each tile has a different number of the item. The game also has a set of numbered wooden discs. I think the players must identify the total when both tiles match, so 4 mice and 6 mice makes 10 mice.

Ages 5 and up.

17314.name: Billo
17314.description:
Perfect information, no luck involved abstract strategy game.

A checkers variant on the classic 8*8 square board.

Every player has two kinds of pieces: round ones and square ones. Square pieces have an hole and round pieces fit into the hole, so two pieces of the same color of different shapes can share the same space.

Square pieces capture opponent's round ones.
Round pieces capture opponent's square ones.

Pieces that reach the opposite side of the board become more powerful, as in checkers.

17315.description:
Each player has 4 penguins. Place your penguins on the board and roll a die to move your penguin. Because of this movement other penguins get closer to the edge of the iceberg. The purpose is to keep your penguins as long as possible on the iceberg. Push other penguins off the ice and win.

From the back of Iceberg box:
The object of the game is to have the only remaining penguin or penguins left on the "iceberg" by pushing opponent's penguins off the "iceberg".
Each player chooses four penguins of the same color and places these on the correctly coloured dots on the playing board. By rolling the die players move either 1, 2 or 3 places to the left or right in order to push other penguins nearer to the edge of the iceberg. or even into the water. A penguin pushed into the water is out of the game. The game is over when only one player's penguin or penguins remain on the "iceberg" and this one remaining player is the winner.

From the back of the Ping Win box:

"The comical penguins have a rare old time playing at pushing each other off the "ice floe". The last player to have a penguin or penguins left on the ice is the winner."
17315.name: Ping Win

17316.name: Strategy: The Game of Armies

boardgameversion.41883: Corey Game Co. 'Knights and Barons' edition

17316.description:
The game of Strategy is played upon a board representing a battlefield, between players who move pieces representing the soldiers and guns of opposing armies across the board and against each other in maneuvers resembling warfare. Each player is equipped at the beginning of the game with an "army" of twenty playing pieces, sixteen representing soldiers and four representing guns.

The board is divided into sectors, if a gun is in a sector, it controls the sector and captures all opposing pieces in the sector. The object is to capture the enemy capital while preventing the enemy from doing the same. A roll of the dice determines how many pieces a player may move in a turn.

17317.description:
Claydonia Conquers the World! is an expansion rule set for Clay-O-Rama. Claydonia Conquers the World! was published in Dragon Magazine #144 pp. 28-31 April 1989. The original Clay-O-Rama game was also published in Dragon Magazine (issue 125) by David "Zeb" Cook.

The original Clay-O-Rama had players make monsters (Claydonians) out of Play-Doh in order to battle each other. Powers from a list were assigned to each monster. Some Powers involve dice-rolling to hit, while others required actual physical actions such as throwing clay missiles or poking a finger through an opponent's monster.

In the Claydonia expansion there are Campaign rules and a list of 15 new Powers. The Campaign rules include Claydonian Experience Level Advancement so monsters who survive can get tougher. The new Powers include dreaded attacks such as "Absorb Opponent", "Use Self as Missile", and "Stomp" (in which a player uses a shoe or boot).

Expands:

Clay-O-Rama
17317.name: Claydonia Conquers the World!

17319.name: Boris Karloff's Monster Game
17319.description: Boris Karloff's Monster Game is a simple spin-and-move game, following a preset path on the game board from start to finish. Along the way there are several detours to Haunted locations. Players move their game pieces along the track and encounter monsters, represented by 31 monster markers, one of which is a depiction of Boris Karloff himself.

17320.description:
Wolfman Mystery Game is a roll-and-move game where players eventually intersect 8 different locations on the game board, such as Skeleton Heap and Headhunters' Isle. There are no shortcuts or detours. Two spinners are provided, one for movement, and the other one for monster encounters.

Contents; Board, 4 player markers with different colored bases, and 2 spinners built into the game box insert.
17320.name: Wolfman Mystery Game

17321.name: Celebrity Monstars
17321.description:
A game for 2-6 players Ages 12 and up

Components:
6 Operating Tables
1 D8
104 Cards

The object of the game is to build a Monstar from parts of well known (in 1989) (mostly UK) Celebrities.

Each Monstar requires 7 parts - head, chest, right arm, left arm, stomach, right leg and left leg, and must be constructed in sequence.

Body parts are dealt from the pack with each player only retaining 3 cards in his or her hand.

There are essentially only two options available to a player during their turn:
Lay a body part card, or
Roll the dice.

Dependant on the dice roll a player will either:
- Draw or nominate someone else to draw from a deck of "event" cards. This generally results in gaining or losing body parts for/from your Monstar.
- take a card from another player's hand
- Steal body parts from an opponent's "freezer".
- Steal body parts from an opponent's partilaly completed Monstar.

First to complete his or her Monstar and bring it to life through the use of an "Igor" card is the winner.

206256.name: Kitty Chaos: Get Me Outta Here Promo Card

17323.description:
Run Kitty Run! In Kitty Chaos, four kittens have made a daring escape from the clutches of the evil City Pound, which snatches the felines from their owners and sells them to the fatal fur trade.

Now they must make their way back through the suburban streets to their loving owners. Unfortunately, their trek is troubled with danger; from vicious dogs to malicious kids, these furry felines have a chaotic adventure in front of them, as the pound van doesn't give up its chase along the way. Your job is to get your kitty back to its correct owner. Luckily, you have nine lives to help you get there - so be the first player to reach your owner's home and win the game!
17323.name: Kitty Chaos

17324.name: Decimeter Game
17324.description:
Appropriate for Grades 6-10

This game teaches the commonly used units of the metric system with questions involving everyday shopping situations. It also gives practice in simple math.

Players move around a colorful board which presents and reinforces the concepts. There are separate decks of question cards which allow beginning and advanced players to participate together.

Game Includes: game board, dice, 60 centimeter cubes, question cards and chance cards for both beginning and advanced players, instructions, and an answer key.

17325.name: Winner's Eye View
17325.description:
Winner's Eye View is an auto racing game designed and published by a British race car driver and instructor.

The rules are fairly similar to those of the Avalon Hill version of Speed Circuit. Cars are built by choosing levels of gearing, amount of fuel, type of tires, etc. Speeds are chosen simultaneously on dashboards (which are also used to track fuel, tire wear, oil pressure, etc.) with maximum acceleration and braking amounts being observed (although you can exceed them if you roll for penalties). Corners have maximum speeds posted in each space, although they can be exceeded for more penalty chart rolls or by staying on the racing line. There are rules for slipstreaming and pitting.

The game elaborates somewhat on the basic Speed Circuit model. It tracks wear separately for front and rear tires, has a few extra cornering rules, and has optional weather rules (this is where the different tire types come into play). The movement is also more fine-grained than in Speed Circuit - here cars move one space for every 10 mph instead of for every 20 mph.

One track (Monaco) is provided on 10 A4 sheets which need to be taped together, and possibly trimmed. Metal F1 cars are provided, as are metal arrows for the dashboard panels.

17326.name: Princess's Court
17326.description: A Japanese card game. The game consists of 110 regular playing card sized cards and a one-page rules sheet in Japanese. The game is similar in play to Uno. Each player plays one card in turn, matching against the last card played in color or value, or drawing a card if not able to do so. The first player to go out scores 0 points for the round, with the remaining players scoring points for the cards remaining in their hands. The game is played in a series of rounds until one player has scored 500 or more points. When that happens, the player with the lowest number of points wins. If a player happens to score exactly 500 points, his score is halved to 250.

17327.name: Mestieri
17327.description:
Mestieri (The Game of Trades) is an Italian card-game using a non-standard deck of 52 cards for 2 or 4 players. The cards are divided into 4 suits, each suit representing a trade: Mechanic, Bricklayer, Farmer or Carpenter. The cards within each suit do not have ranks and display tools or supplies that trade would use. For example, the Farmer cards include seed, a tractor and a scythe. Some cards belong to more than one suit (e.g. the bucket belongs to both the Bricklayer and Farmer suits). In addition, there is a fifth suit, labeled with a 'T'. These cards bear generic goodies like money, Industry, a first aid box and a 'Good Luck' card.

At the start of the game, each player receives a card specifying his trade for that hand. The object is to collect as many cards as you can that belong to your trade. At each turn, you pick one card from the previous player's unused cards. If it belongs to your suit, you add it to your sequence. Otherwise, it joins your unused cards which you then offer to the next player, who will pick a card, and so on. 'T' cards are wild cards that you can add to your sequence. There are three 'T' cards with a '?' on them and the words 'dillo tu' (name me). You can only add these cards to your sequence if you can name a tool/object that fits with your trade and is not already used in the game. The 'Good Luck' card has the power of negating an unused card in your hand - if you have the 'Good Luck' card and only one unused card, you can end the game immediately.

The game ends when any player runs out of unused cards. Unused cards count as penalties (I assume this means they subtract one from the length of your sequence). The winner of the game is the player with the longest sequence of cards bearing objects of their trade.

17328.description:
Crocodile Egg. 24 square tiles show various crocodiles hatching from their eggs. You have to get the heads and tails to match, coming out of the right egg. Very cute graphics.

Ages 5 and up.
17328.name: Kroko-Ei

126484.name: Animal Circus (fan expansion for Animal Upon Animal)

boardgamehonor.19201: 2005 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Childgame Nominee

17329.description:
The animals want to show how good they are at making tall pyramids! They must be skillfully careful: Who will position the penguin on top of the crocodile, the sheep on top of the penguin, the serpent on the sheep? The hedgehog wants to stand on top of the pyramid but the height is making him dizzy.

Tier auf Tier (a.k.a. Animal Upon Animal, Pyramide d'animaux, and Dier op dier) is a simple stacking game, listed for ages 4-99, with 29 cute wooden animals.

Each turn a player rolls the die and either places one or two animals on to the stack of animals, passes one of his or her animals to another player for them to place, or places an animal on the table, extending the base for other players to build upon. Of course, if any pieces fall off whilst you are building, you get up to two of them back. The first player to have used all of their animals wins.

This game, intended for children, is equally popular with adults.
17329.name: Animal Upon Animal

17330.name: Oscar: The Film Star's Rise to Fame
17330.description:
Oscar is a board game based on the "golden age of cinema". The players take the role of actors and actresses trying to become Hollywood stars and win an Academy Award. Players advance by collecting money and assets, avoiding setbacks and win the game by winning the Oscar.

The game contents:
1 game board
15 cardboard character pieces that can be inserted into the plastic playing pieces
6 different colored plastic playing pieces
Paper money
Casting cards
Fortune cards
Asset cards
Loan cards
1 standard six sided die
1 colored die with each side matching the color of one of the 6 playing pieces
1 plastic Oscar bust

17331.name: Sovereign Seas Lite
17331.description:
Sovereign Seas Lite is a nautical combat war game which simulates the period from 1860-1870. Sovereign Seas Lite is intended for 2 or more players. Complexity is medium. Time to learn is from 30-45 minutes.

Sovereign Seas Lite is the early descendant of Queen Victoria's Navy, a significantly updated and more refined game that covers naval combat from 1860 to 1906.

Players assume the role of either the British or the French in an attempt to meet the victory conditions of several different scenarios.

Sovereign Seas Lite uses EOR (See Designer Notes March 97), so any kind of dice can be used in any combination.

The Addendum #1 for Sovereign Seas Lite is a collection of beta rules and Design Your Own information for the Sovereign Seas Lite game system. The addendum includes instructions for Design Your Own ship designs, the beta V3.0 rules of SSL, and the original ship lists from v1.0 of Sovereign Seas. This addendum is not a complete game and is intended as an unofficial supplement to the Sovereign Seas Lite game system.

17332.name: Combat Operations
17332.description: A counter and hex based war game, using a diceless combat system. ComOps is a somewhat generic war game system, that can be used to play many different types of combat. This public beta 1 release includes the rules, the map, the counters, and the few tables needed. A primary goal of ComOps was to present a 'real' war gamers war game, that can be played from setup to end in a reasonable amount of time. At this time no further work is being done on ComOps.

17333.name: Eddie Cantor's Game: Tell It to the Judge
17333.description: This game features a caricature of entertainer Eddie Cantor on the box and a photo of him on the board, though the singer/comic's persona has little do with the game. Players move their pawns (representing automobiles) around the board by playing cards that represent traffic signals. A twist to the game involves the "To See the Judge" spaces on the board. Land on one and and you must draw a summons card, and then the player designated as the judge (he wears a badge that is included) gives the player a fine. The winner is the player who reaches "The Club" and has the most amount of money left once all players are finished.

17334.name: Consequences
17334.description:
CONSEQUENCES - The Game of Decisions, Dilemmas and Deceit

From the Box

"What would be the consequences if you turned up at a fancy-dress party dressed as St George (complete with his dragon) only to discover everyone else in dinner dress?
Or what if you accidentally ran over the neighbor's cat, and no-one saw you do it?
Do you know what you would do?
Can you be sure your friends would do the same?
Find out in this hilarious board game of decisions, dilemmas and dishing the dirt.
Dishonesty has never been such fun!"

Contents:

Playing Board
200 Consequence Cards
24 Voting Cards
Special dice (4 faces show a "voting" symbol, 2 a "writing" symbol)
Playing pieces

During a player's turn the scenario on a Consequence Card is read out. Dependant on the role of a dice players then Vote (using three voting cards) on three possible answers (also on the card), or write down their answer.

Points are awarded for matching responses with other players, with progress being recorded by the movement of a playing piece on a score-board. The first player to 15 points is the winner.

17335.description:
Second expansion for the game Hard Vacuum, it is freely downloadable from here.

It contains Russian and Japanese spaceships, the battle for the moon, and other stuff.

Expands

Hard Vacuum
17335.name: Hard Vacuum: War's End

17337.name: Life Begins at 40
17337.description:
From the box

LIFE BEGINS AT 40 - Survive until you're 40. Then it's fun all the way in this exciting new board game!

SURVIVE UNTIL YOU'RE 40?
In the first part of this fun-packed board game each player has to reach the great age of 40. Along then way you'll be collecting all those responsibilities like kids, house, car and mother-in-law...and paying for their upkeep, whilst trying to maintain a cash balance - and a sense of humor. The quicker you reach 40 the less responsibilities you'll take on!

THEN IT'S FUN ALL THE WAY!
The second part of the game is a race to early retirement, the first player there being the winner. But you can't win however while you still have the responsibility of a Bank Loan, Mortgage or kids - so they'll have to go!

17338.name: Hullabaloo
17338.description:
HULLABALOO - The Classic game of Noisy Charades.

From the box:

"Welcome to the loudest, most frantic, most hilarious game you'll ever play! That's because in HULLABALOO you can only use the "language" of noise to make yourself understood ... and all in just 30 seconds.

You'll have you team mates in stitches guessing your "noise", whether it's a One Armed bandit, a Fun Fair or laying an Egg!

Does your team have the skill to reach the ON square before your opponents? There is only one way to find out - play HULLABALOO and discover for yourself why it's the game everyone's making such a noise about."

17339.description:
Stars and Stripes is a supplement for Flames of War: The World War II Miniatures Game, the World War II miniatures game. It provides the complete organization and equipment for US infantry and armored forces in North Africa and the Mediterranean. Also included are variants for Ranger Company, Parachute Rifle Company and Armored Recon Company. History of 'Bid Red One' Infantry Division is also provided.

There are new Reconnaissance rules, tactics guide, painting guide, three American Warriors and two new missions for Flames of War.
17339.name: Stars and Stripes: Intelligence Handbook on US Armored and Infantry Forces

11168.name: Flames of War: The World War II Miniatures Game

17340.description:
Stalingrad is a supplement for Flames of War: The World War II Miniatures Game, the World War II miniatures game. It provides the organization and equipment for the Soviet and German Infantry Forces involved in the battle for Stalingrad.

For the Soviet, there are covers special rules and full stats on the Soviet equipment, guns, vehicles and teams. There are organisation lists for Strelkovy Batalon (Infantry Battalion), Guardeyskiy Strelkovy Batalon (Guard Infantry Battalion) and Batalon Opolecheniya (Militia Battalion). The second two are variations on the Strelkovy Batalon, allowing for either better-trained troops (Guards) or lower motivation (Militia).

The German forces found in this book are the Grenadiers: Grenadierkompanie, Schnellschwadron, Pionierkompanie and Luftwaffe Feldkompanie.

Street Fighting Rules are also included as well as tactics articles, painting guide, rules for warriors and snipers and new scenarios.
17340.name: Stalingrad: Intelligence Handbook on Soviet and German Infantry Forces

11168.name: Flames of War: The World War II Miniatures Game

17341.name: Desert Fox
17341.description:
Subtitled 'Intelligence Handbook on German Armored Forces in North Africa', this is a supplement for Flames of War: The World War II Miniatures Game the World War II Miniatures game.

The book has complete organization and equipment for German Armored forces in North Africa, variants for engineer, armored grenadier and reconnaissance companies, history of the Afrikakorps, tactics guide, painting guide, new missions and new warriors.

17342.description:
Subtitled 'Intelligence Handbook on German Airborne Forces', this is a supplement for Flames of War: The World War II Miniatures Game the World War II Miniatures game.

The book has complete organization and equipment for the Diving Eagles, variants for early and late war battles, history of the German airborne forces, tactics guide, painting guide, new missions and new warriors.
17342.name: Diving Eagles

11168.name: Flames of War: The World War II Miniatures Game

boardgamehonor.20899: 2004 Origins Awards Gamers’ Choice Award Winner

17343.description:
Subtitled 'Intelligence Handbook on British Armored Forces', this is a supplement for Flames of War the World War II Miniatures game.

The book has complete organization and equipment for British Armored, Motor and Armored Car forces in North Africa and Italy, variants for the Death or Glory Boys, history of the Desert Rats, the 7th Armored Division, new anti-tank gun rules, tactics guide, painting guide, new missions and new warriors.
17343.name: Desert Rats

11168.name: Flames of War: The World War II Miniatures Game

17344.name: Old Ironsides
17344.description:
Subtitled 'Intelligence Handbook on US Armored Forces', this is a supplement for Flames of War the World War II Miniatures game.

The book has complete organization and equipment for US Armored forces in North Africa and the Mediterranean, variants for early war Tank companies, Armored Recon and Truck-borne companies, history of the 1st Old Ironsides' Armored Division, new reconnaissance rules, tactics guide, painting guide, new missions and new warriors.

17345.name: City State Warfare
17345.description:
City State Warfare is a tactical combat game set in the Fantastic Era, a place in time and space where technology is Medieval to early Renaissance and the legends live. This is the age in which most Fantasy Role Playing (FRP) Games take place. City State warfare is a medium for resolving the larger conflicts which would normally be handled with large miniature battles. This game may also be used to recreate the epic battles of fantasy literature. -- from the Introduction

This is a standard boardgame of the time, with some fantasy elements thrown in. It also has scenarios for historical battles such as Tours (732), Hastings (1066), Liegnitz (1241), Morgarten (1315), and a few others. It is an easy hex-and-counter game by grognard standards.

17346.name: Moon Race
17346.description:
"A game for young astronauts of all ages"
"Computers Decide Progress"

The board (18" x 14" approx) is a cardboard sandwich containing a rotating wheel. Each player uses a pencil or matchstick (not supplied) to rotate the wheel, which changes the what is shown in the various pre-cut windows. This includes the distance the player's rocket must move, and good or bad events resulting from landing on certain spaces. There is no interaction: it is purely a race.

17347.description:
Champions is a fantasy fighting CCG. To quote the rules: "There are two sets of Champions Battle Cards 'Monster Wars' and 'Medieval Battle'. In each series there are two sets of cards, Monsters or Warriors (Characters) and Spells or Weapons (Specials). Spells are used by Monsters to increase their fighting strength; likewise Warriors use Weapons."

The Character Cards are printed with attack and defense values, and the Specials have either an attack or a defense value. All have some artwork and (tongue-in-cheek) text. The Character Cards also have scratch-off areas.

During the game each player has a hand of 5 cards and a deck of 15. The first player attacks with 1, 2 or 3 Character cards and some number of Special cards, and the other tries to defend against each attacking Character by laying down a Character and Specials having the same or higher value.

The unique feature is that, according to the rules, each losing Character has a scratch-off area removed, which shows a new and "almost always" weaker attack or defense value. The final scratch-off is always zero, at which time the card "needs replacing". So not only are the cards collectible, they are also destructible!
17347.name: Champions

17348.name: InuYasha TCG
17348.description:
From the Inuyasha TCG website:

This game has 4 card types: characters, items, locations and events.


Characters (white) are personalities in the Inuyasha storyline.
Items (red) are the things that they use.
Locations (green) are the places they go.
Events (blue) are the plot twists that push the story and game along.


Two Ways to Win:


STEAL ALL 10 SHIKON JEWEL SHARDS! — You win the instant you control all 10 Shards. Shards are facedown cards that you both set aside when the game begins. You steal shards by defeating characters, attacking your opponent directly, and by using game effects.
EMPTY YOUR OPPONENT’S DECK! — You win the instant your opponent tries to draw or discard a card from his or her deck and cannot.


GETTING STARTED: First you need a deck of exactly 60 cards. The rules for deck building are easy: Unless the card restricts itself, you can have as many copies of a card you want.

17349.description:
From the White Mask Productions website:

Gorilla Warfare is a primal game of explosive jungle combat. Every player controls a team of four gorillas; armed with bulging muscles, bad tempers, and explosive Banana Grenades. The object? To be the king of the jungle, of course.

"Gorilla Warfare is here and ready to play! The entire game took only 24 hours to create, but I tell you this; it almost ranks up there with Empires in playable fun. I always like moving my Gorillas around like a S.W.A.T. Team. No one can sneak up on you, and if anyone gets too close, all four Gorilla's are just about in equal throwing distance to fry the primate. Of course, this is a bad idea if an enemy has a Class 5 Banana Grenade, as the explosion can wipe out a good part of the play field..."

Outdated link:
View the rules, FAq, etc at http://www.whitemask.com/gorilla/
17349.name: Gorilla Warfare

17351.name: IQuest
17351.description:
Contents:

1 playing board
2,200 Questions and Answers
6 Playing "I"s
32 Scoring "Q"s
6 I agree / I Disagree cards
1 Timer

From the rule book:

"IQuest provides an absorbing challenge which allows players to explore their own abilities to think creatively. A range of fascinating word, number, shape and language puzzles in an intriguing variety of game categories awaits you for your quest through the IQuset maze. Whether you wrangle with a Rangle, or stumble over a Numble, IQuest provides fun and fascination for adults and children alike."

Players must correctly answer a series of questions, at least one in each of five categories, in order to progress towards the sunburst located in the middle of the board.

Players are allowed up to one minute to answer the questions, whilst the other players may choose to agree or disagree with the answer given. Correct answers result in movement of playing pieces and the receipt of Scoring "Q"s.

The first player to place his/her token on the sunburst and correctly answer an IQuest category question wins the game.

17352.name: Subbuteo Cricket
17352.description:
Subbuteo Cricket continued the line of sporting dexterity games started by Subbuteo football (soccer). The game was played on a green beige mat, similar to that use for the soccer version. The rules mimicked those of cricket (which will doubtless make this review impenetrable to most nationalities).

The bowling side placed the small red plastic ball in the channel in the bowling piece, which was then flicked to propel the ball towards the batsman and a small plastic wicket (complete with separate plastic bails). The batting action was achieved by spinning a handle attached to a small plastic cricket bat, aiming to hit the ball to score runs; the number of runs scored depended on the distance the ball was hit.

The fielding side set out its players, which were small plastic men each on a molded plastic base which included a cup-shaped depression. If the ball was hit into one of these depressions, that was a catch.
